{{Infobox book | name = 1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die | image = 1001moviescover.jpg | caption = The cover of the 2nd edition,
with a [[film still|still]] from ''[[Psycho (1960 film)|Psycho]]''. | author = Steven Jay Schneider, general editor | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = [[Quintessence Editions]], sholay biya ''The 1001 Before You Die series'' | subject = [[Film]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | published = 13 November 2003 ([[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell Illustrated]]) | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = 960 (1st edition) | isbn = 978-1-84403-044-6 | oclc = 223768961 | dewey = | congress = PN1998 .A16 2003 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die''''' is a film reference book edited by Steven Jay Schneider with original essays on each film contributed by over 70 film critics. It is a part of a series designed and produced by [[Quintessence Editions]], a London-based company, and published in English-language versions by [[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell Illustrated]] (UK), ABC Books (the publishing division of [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]), and [[Barron's Educational Series|Barron's]] (US). The first edition was published in 2003; the most recent edition was published in 2018. Contributors include [[Adrian Martin]], [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]], [[Richard Peña]], [[David Stratton]], and [[Margaret Pomeranz]]. Each title is accompanied by a brief synopsis and critique, some with photographs. Presented chronologically, the 7th edition begins with [[Georges Méliès]]' ''[[A Trip to the Moon]]'' from [[1902 in film|1902]] and ends in 2016 with [[Moonlight (2016 film)|''Moonlight'']]. The book has been popular in Australia, where it was the seventh best-selling book in the country for a week in April 2004{{cite news|url=http://www.newstext.com.au/docs/STE/2004/get.jsp?docid=STE-20040418-1-088-4134004V1@NSW-METRO-2004-2003|title=Best sellers|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Sunday {{short description| Proclamation restoring an independent State of Lithuania }} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} [[File:Original Act of Independence of Lithuania hand-written in Lithuanian language.jpg|thumb|right|The original hand-written Act of Independence of Lithuania with twenty original signatures of signatories]] [[File:Nepriklausomybes aktas.gif|thumb|right|Facsimile of the Act of 16 February]] The '''Act of Reinstating Independence of Lithuania''' ({{lang-lt|Lietuvos Valstybės atkūrimo aktas}}) or '''Act of 16 February''' was signed by the [[Council of Lithuania]] on 16 February 1918, proclaiming the restoration of an independent State of [[Lithuania]], governed by [[democracy|democratic]] principles, with [[Vilnius]] as its capital. The Act was signed by all [[Signatories of the Act of Independence of Lithuania|twenty representatives]] of the Council, which was chaired by [[Jonas Basanavičius]]. The Act of 16 February was the result of a series of resolutions on the issue, including one issued by the [[Vilnius Conference]] and the Act of 8 January. The path to the Act was long and complex because the [[German Empire]] exerted pressure on the Council to form an alliance. The Council had to carefully maneuver between the Germans, whose troops were present in Lithuania, and the demands of the Lithuanian people.
The immediate effects of the announcement of Lithuania's re-establishment of independence were limited. Publication of the Act was prohibited by the German authorities, and the text was distributed and printed illegally. The work of the Council was hindered, and Germans remained in control over Lithuania.<ref name=el /> The situation changed only when Germany lost [[World War I]] in the fall of 1918. In November 1918 the first Cabinet of Lithuania was formed, and the Council of Lithuania gained control over the territory of Lithuania.<ref>{{cite book| first=Vytas Stanley |last=Vardys |author2=Judith B. Sedaitis |title=Lithuania: The Rebel Nation |publisher=[[Westview Press]] |location=[[Boulder, CO]] |year=1997 |series=Westview Series on the Post-Soviet Republics |isbn=0-8133-1839-4 |pages=22–23}}</ref> Independent Lithuania, although it would soon be battling the [[Lithuanian Wars of Independence|Wars of Independence]], became a reality.
The laconic Act is the legal basis for the existence of modern Lithuania, both during the [[interwar period]] and since 1990.<ref name=maks /> The Act formulated the basic constitutional principles that were and still are followed by all [[Constitution of Lithuania|Constitutions of Lithuania]]. The Act itself was a key element in the foundation of Lithuania's [[Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania|re-establishment of independence in 1990]].<ref name=VAR /> Lithuania, breaking away from the [[Soviet Union]], stressed that it was simply re-establishing the independent state that existed between the world wars and that the Act never lost its legal power.<ref name=LRS />
On 29 March 2017, the original document was found at the Diplomatic archive in Berlin, Germany.
==Historic background and Council of Lithuania== Lithuania had a centuries long tradition of statehood following the coronation of [[Mindaugas]] the [[King of Lithuania]]. {{Main|Council of Lithuania}} [[File:Signatarai.Signatories of Lithuania.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The original 20 members of the Council of Lithuania after signing the Act of 16 February 1918]] After the last [[partitions of Poland|Partition of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] in 1795, Lithuania was annexed by the [[Russian Empire]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Grenoble |first=Lenore |title=Language Policy in the Soviet Union |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nn3xDTiL0PQC&pg=PA104 |year=2003 |volume=3 |series=Language policy |publisher=Kluwer Academic Publishers |location=Dordrecht |pages=104 |isbn=1-4020-1298-5 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617163656/https://books.google.com/books?id=Nn3xDTiL0PQC&pg=PA104 |archivedate=2016-06-17 |df= }}</ref> During the 19th century, both the Lithuanians and the [[Poland|Poles]] attempted to restore their independence. Lithuanians rebelled during the 1830 [[November Uprising]] and the 1863 [[January Uprising]], but their first real opportunity arose when both Russia and Germany were weakened during [[World War I]].<ref name="Nicolson2014">{{cite book|author=Colin Nicolson|title=Longman Companion to the First World War: Europe 1914–1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ttQFBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA239|date=15 July 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-88826-0|page=239|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611022049/https://books.google.com/books?id=ttQFBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA239|archivedate=11 June 2016|df=}}</ref>
In 1915, Germany occupied western parts of the [[Russian Empire]]. After the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]] in 1917, Germany conceived the geopolitical strategy of [[Mitteleuropa]] – a regional network of [[puppet state]]s that would serve as a buffer zone – and agreed to allow the [[Vilnius Conference]], hoping that it would proclaim that the Lithuanian nation wanted to detach itself from Russia and establish a closer relationship with Germany.<ref name=el>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Council of Lithuania | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = I | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages = 581–585}}</ref> However, this strategy backfired; the conference, held on 18–22 September 1917, adopted a resolution that an independent Lithuania should be established and that a closer relationship with Germany would be conditional on Germany's formal recognition of the new state.<ref name=Lina>{{cite book |last= Kulikauskienė |first= Lina |chapter= 1917 metų Lietuvos Taryba |title=Gimtoji istorija. Nuo 7 iki 12 klasės |year=2002| chapterurl=http://mkp.emokykla.lt/gimtoji/?id=9410 |publisher=Elektroninės leidybos namai |location= Vilnius| isbn=9986-9216-9-4|language=lt}}</ref> On 21 September, the 214 attendees at the conference elected a 20-member [[Council of Lithuania]] to codify this resolution.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.patriotas.lt/2002-1vas.htm |title=Kelio į Vasario 16-tąją pradžia ir vyriausybės sudarymas| accessdate=2007-01-29| first=Jonas |last=Jusaitis| journal=Patriotas |date=February 2002 |volume=2 |issue=37 |issn=1648-1232 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070506063343/http://www.patriotas.lt/2002-1vas.htm |archivedate=2007-05-06 |language=lt}}</ref> The German authorities did not allow that resolution to be published, but they did permit the Council to proceed.<ref name=el /> The Vilnius Conference also resolved that a constituent assembly be elected "in conformity with democratic principles by all the inhabitants of Lithuania".<ref name="Ashbourne1999">{{cite book|author=Alexandra Ashbourne|title=Lithuania: The Rebirth of a Nation, 1991–1994|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yFoDJUq4qjQC&pg=PA11|date=1 January 1999|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=978-0-7391-0027-1|page=11|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508121130/https://books.google.com/books?id=yFoDJUq4qjQC&pg=PA11|archivedate=8 May 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Path to the Act of 16 February==
===Act of 11 December=== The Act of 11 December was the second stage in the progression towards the final Act of Independence. The first draft, demanded by chancellor [[Georg von Hertling]], was prepared by the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs on December 1.<ref name=eidintas /> Further changes were jointly prepared by the German chancellery and by a delegation of the Council of Lithuania. The delegation's members were [[Antanas Smetona]], [[Steponas Kairys]], [[Vladas Mironas]], [[Jurgis Šaulys]], [[Petras Klimas]] and [[Aleksandras Stulginskis]].<ref name=Raimundas>{{cite journal |url=http://www.ceeol.com/aspx/getdocument.aspx?logid=5&id=8e57bf2c-f20c-494d-8b04-9bfedd6a3fbd |title=Vasario 16-osios aktas: teksto formavimo šaltiniai ir autorystės problema |first=Raimundas |last=Klimavičius |journal=Istorija. Lietuvos aukštųjų mokyklų mokslo darbai |publisher=[[Vilnius Pedagogical University]] |year=2004 |issue=59–60 |pages=57–66 |issn=1392-0456 |language=lt |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926230042/http://www.ceeol.com/aspx/getdocument.aspx?logid=5&id=8e57bf2c-f20c-494d-8b04-9bfedd6a3fbd |archivedate=2007-09-26 |df= }}</ref> After discussion amongst the parties, a compromise was reached on the document's text. The German representative, Kurt von Lersner, insisted that not one word be changed in the agreed-upon text and that all the Council members sign the document.<ref name=Raimundas />
After the delegation returned to Vilnius, a session of the Council was held on 11 December in order to discuss the Act. It was adopted without any further changes. Fifteen voted in favor of the Act, three voted against it, one member abstained, and one did not participate.<ref name=Raimundas /> It is not entirely clear whether every member of the Council signed this document.<ref name=Raimundas /> The Act was written in [[German language|German]], and apparently no official Lithuanian translation was prepared. Therefore, different sources provide slightly different translations.<ref name=Raimundas /> The Act of 11 December pronounced Lithuania's independence, but also asked German government for protection (clause 2) and called for "a firm and permanent alliance" with Germany.<ref name=Lina /> Since the Act specified that the alliance was to be formed based on conventions concerning military affairs, transportation, customs, and currency, many Lithuanians argued that the Council had overstepped its authority: the September resolution adopted by the Vilnius Conference clearly demanded that a constituent assembly decide these crucial matters of state.<ref name=eidintas />
===Act of 8 January=== [[File:Jonas Basanavicius (1851-1927).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Jonas Basanavičius]], the chairman of the Council when the Act of 16 February was signed]] When peace talks started between Germany and Russia in 1918, German authorities asked the [[Lithuanians|Lithuanian]] representatives to prepare two notifications of independence—one for Russia, in which Lithuania's ties with Russia would be denounced and nothing would be mentioned about an alliance with Germany, and a version to be released in Germany that would essentially repeat the Act of 11 December.<ref name=Raimundas /> The Council decided to amend the first part of the Act of 11 December. [[Petras Klimas]] included a sentence calling for the Constituent Assembly.<ref name=Skirius>{{cite book |last=Skirius|first=Juozas |chapterurl=http://mkp.emokykla.lt/gimtoji/?id=1012 |accessdate=2007-01-27 |chapter=Lietuvos nepriklausomybės akto paskelbimas |title=Gimtoji istorija. Nuo 7 iki 12 klasės | year=2002| location=Vilnius |publisher=Elektroninės leidybos namai |isbn=9986-9216-9-4|language=lt}}</ref> Another important development was the statement that democratic principles would be the basis of the new state's governance,<ref name=Raimundas /> something that was declared by the Vilnius Conference, but omitted in the Act of 11 December.<ref name=MG>{{cite journal |title=Jonas Vileišis ir Vasario 16-osios Aktas |url=http://ausis.gf.vu.lt/mg/nr/2001/12/12v.html |first=Dobilas |last=Kirvelis |journal=Mokslas ir gyvenimas |year=2001 |volume=12 |issue=528 |issn=0134-3084 |language=lt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060927183000/http://ausis.gf.vu.lt/mg/nr/2001/12/12v.html |archivedate=2006-09-27 |df= }}</ref> The second part, mentioning the "firm and permanent alliance with Germany", was completely omitted.<ref name=Skirius /> Its final version was approved on 8 January 1918, the day that [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Woodrow Wilson]] announced his [[Fourteen Points]]. In its essence, the Act of 8 January did not differ from the Act of 16 February.<ref name=MG />
However, [[Ober Ost]], the German military administration, rejected the changes. On 26 January, in compliance with the earlier request, the two versions of the notification were approved, but they did not include the changes of 8 January.<ref name=Skirius /> The texts were prepared based on the Act of 11 December. These concessions to the Germans created tensions among the council members.<ref name=gerutis /> Four members – [[Mykolas Biržiška]], [[Steponas Kairys]], [[Stanisław Narutowicz]] and [[Jonas Vileišis]] – resigned from the Council in protest.<ref name=eidintas /> Chairman [[Antanas Smetona]], who supported the Act of 11 December, stepped down.<ref name=MG /> Jonas Basanavičius, who would later be called the patriarch of independence, was elected chairman.<ref>{{cite book |last=Nezabitauskas |first=Adolfas |title=Jonas Basanavičius| year=1990| page=6| publisher=Vaga |location=Vilnius| isbn=5-415-00640-0|language=lt}}</ref>
===Act of 16 February=== Germany failed to recognize Lithuania as an independent state, and the Lithuanian delegation was not invited to the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk|Brest-Litovsk negotiations]] that started on 22 December 1917, between the [[Central Powers]] and [[Russian SFSR|Russia]] in order to settle territorial claims.<ref name=gerutis /> During the first and final official joint session between the Council and the German authorities, it was made clear that the Council would serve only as an advisory board.<ref name=Skirius /> This situation gave additional backing to those Council members who were seeking independence without any ties to other countries. The prime concern at this point was to invite back those members who had left the Council. Negotiations were undertaken that led to the reformulation of previous versions of the Act.<ref name=eidintas />
The four withdrawn members demanded that the Council return to the Act of 8 January and omit the mention of any alliance with Germany.<ref name=Raimundas /> After heated debates that lasted for several weeks, on 15 February, at 10 am, the new revision of the Act was ready. It included, with minor stylistic changes, wording of the Act of 8 January and [[promulgation]] and notification, drafted on 1 February. Promulgation and notification do not carry legal weight and do not change the meaning of a legal document.<ref name=Raimundas /> The Council, including the withdrawn members, was invited to return the next day for its finalization. On the next day, 16 February 1918, at 12:30 pm, all twenty Council members met in the room of Lithuanian Committee for Support of the War Victims, at 30 [[Didžioji Street]] in Vilnius.<ref name=Skirius /> The building has since been known as the [[House of the Signatories]] ({{lang-lt|signatarų namai}}) and houses a museum. The Council first voted to approve the first part, the first two paragraphs up to the word ''drauge'', of the Act. This section was approved unanimously.<ref name=maks>{{cite book| first=Mindaugas |last=Maksimaitis |title=Lietuvos valstybės konstitucijų istorija (XX a. pirmoji pusė) |publisher=Justitia |location=Vilnius |year=2005 |isbn=9955-616-09-1 |pages=36–44|language=lt}}</ref> The second part, however, did not receive support from the four withdrawn members because they were not satisfied with the word "''finally''" in describing the duties of the Constituent Assembly (in "''... the foundation of the Lithuanian State and its relations with other countries will be finally determined by the Constituent Assembly ...''").<ref name=maks /> They were afraid that this word would give a pretext for the Council to usurp the powers of the Constituent Assembly, while the majority argued that the word simply expressed the non-negotiable and non-appealable nature of the future Assembly's decisions.<ref name=Raimundas /> Therefore, the Act was unanimously approved ''[[:wiktionary:en bloc|en bloc]]'' but did not have full-fledged support from all twenty men.<ref name=maks />

==Aftermath==
===Lithuania=== [[File:Lietuvos aidas independence.jpg|thumb|220px|The front page of ''Lietuvos aidas'' with the text of the Act. The bulk of the issue was confiscated by German authorities.]] Soon after the signing, the Act was taken to Germany and handed to parties in the [[Reichstag (German Empire)|Reichstag]]. On 18 February, the text was reprinted in German newspapers, including ''[[Das Neue Litauen]]'', ''[[Vossische Zeitung]]'', ''[[Taegliche Rundschau]]'' and ''[[Kreuzzeitung]]''.<ref name=el /> In Lithuania a text of the proclamation was prepared for printing in newspapers, particularly in ''[[Lietuvos aidas]]'', the Council's newspaper established by Antanas Smetona; but the German authorities prohibited this publication. Although the majority of the copies of the issue were confiscated, the newspaper's editor, [[Petras Klimas]], managed to hide about 60 of them.<ref name=Skirius />
On 3 March 1918, Germany and the now-[[Bolshevik]] [[Russian SFSR|Russia]] signed the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]]. It declared that the [[Baltic states|Baltic nations]] were in the German interest zone and that Russia renounced any claims to them. On 23 March, Germany recognized independent Lithuania on the basis of the 11 December declaration.<ref name=el /> However, in substance, nothing had changed either in Lithuania or in the Council's status: any efforts to establish an administration were hindered.<ref name=gerutis>{{cite book |last=Gerutis |first=Albertas |editor= Albertas Gerutis |others= translated by Algirdas Budreckis|title= Lithuania: 700 Years |year=1984 |edition=6th |publisher= Manyland Books|location= New York|isbn=0-87141-028-1 |pages=151–162 |chapter=Independent Lithuania}}</ref> This situation changed when the [[German Revolution]] started and Germany lost the war in the fall of 1918 – it was no longer in a position to dictate terms. The Council of Lithuania adopted the first provisional constitution on 2 November. The functions of government were entrusted to a three-member presidium, and [[Augustinas Voldemaras]] was invited to form the first Cabinet of Ministers of Lithuania.<ref name=eidintas>{{cite book |last=Eidintas |first=Alfonsas |author2=Vytautas Žalys |author3=[[Alfred Erich Senn]] |editor=Edvardas Tuskenis |title=Lithuania in European Politics: The Years of the First Republic, 1918–1940 |edition=Paperback |date=September 1999 |publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]] |location=New York |isbn=0-312-22458-3 |pages=24–31 |chapter=Chapter 1: Restoration of the State }}</ref> Complete international recognition took several years; the US affirmed it on 22 July 1922.<ref name="Lauterpacht2012">{{cite book|author=Hersch Lauterpacht|title=Recognition in International Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EWgEv1Qq2TwC&pg=PA11|date=1 November 2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-60943-3|page=11|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160502154217/https://books.google.com/books?id=EWgEv1Qq2TwC&pg=PA11|archivedate=2 May 2016|df=}}</ref>
===The Act=== Two copies of the Act were signed: the original and a duplicate. The original was given to Jonas Basanavičius to safeguard and protect. The original was never published or used in any public matters; its existence was first mentioned in the press in 1933.<ref name=orig>{{cite web|url=http://www.lnm.lt/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=64&Itemid=100 |title=1918 m. vasario 16 d. Lietuvos nepriklausomybės akto pasirašymas| publisher=National Museum of Lithuania |work=Naujausių laikų Lietuvos valstybingumo istorija |accessdate=2007-02-06| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060712195416/http://www.lnm.lt/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=64&Itemid=100| archivedate =2006-07-12|language=lt}}</ref> The duplicate was used in day-to-day business, and was stored in the president's archives until 15 June 1940, the day when Lithuania [[1940 Soviet ultimatum to Lithuania|received an ultimatum from the Soviet Union]] and lost its independence.<ref name=orig /> After that date the document disappeared. Both the original and the duplicate were missing for decades; historians and adventurers hunted for them. In 2006, a team of engineers searched the walls of the [[Vileišis Palace|former house]] of [[Petras Vileišis]].<ref>{{cite web |date=2006-02-13 |title=Viltis rasti Vasario 16-osios akto originalą vis labiau blėsta |url=http://www.lrytas.lt/?id=11398300311138538447&view=4 |publisher=[[Lietuvos rytas]] |accessdate=2007-02-06 |language=lt |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929102545/http://www.lrytas.lt/?id=11398300311138538447&view=4 |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}</ref> Two [[facsimile]]s of the duplicate were produced, one in 1928 and the other in 1933. The 1928 facsimile is a closer reproduction of the Act in its original state. It contains spelling errors and the background is visually "noisy", while the 1933 facsimile shows the Act in an "improved" condition.<ref name=orig />
In 2017, Lithuanian businessman [[Darius Mockus]] offered a 1-million-[[Euro]] reward to anyone who could find the original document and give it to the State of Lithuania. The offer's deadline was set to 16 February 2018, when Lithuania will commemorate the 100th anniversary of its declaration of independence.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rules – Act of Independence of Lithuania|url=http://vasario16aktas.lt/iniciatyvos-pradzia/en/|website=vasario16aktas.lt}}</ref> On 29 March 2017, [[Vytautas Magnus University]] professor [[Liudas Mažylis]] announced he had found the original document in the [[Federal Foreign Office|Federal Foreign Office Political Archive]] in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]], hand-written in the [[Lithuanian language]] and signed by the twenty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Berlyne rastas Vasario 16-osios akto originalas – LRT|url=http://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/168155|website=Lietuvos Radijas ir Televizija|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=lt|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329230720/http://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/lietuvoje/2/168155|archivedate=29 March 2017|df=}}</ref> He also announced that he had found the German-language version of the 16 February 1918 document and the Act of 11 December 1917. The latter displays nineteen signatures (without that of [[Pranas Dovydaitis]]).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beniušis|first1=Vaidotas|title=Berlyne rastas Vasario 16-osios akto originalas lietuvių kalba|url=http://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/berlyne-rastas-vasario-16-osios-akto-originalas-lietuviu-kalba.d?id=74205398|website=DELFI.lt|accessdate=29 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330000949/http://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/berlyne-rastas-vasario-16-osios-akto-originalas-lietuviu-kalba.d?id=74205398|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Stažytė|first1=Karolina|title=Kas tas Liudas Mažylis, atradęs Vasario 16-osios aktą? Lietuvos Šerlokas Holmsas|url=http://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/kas-tas-liudas-mazylis-atrades-vasario-16-osios-akta-lietuvos-serlokas-holmsas-56-776414|website=15min.lt|accessdate=30 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330115317/http://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/kas-tas-liudas-mazylis-atrades-vasario-16-osios-akta-lietuvos-serlokas-holmsas-56-776414|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=}}</ref> Germany confirmed the documents' authenticity on the following day and they were displayed publicly by two officials — [[Michael Roth (politician)|Michael Roth]], the German [[Minister of State#Germany|Minister of State for Europe]], and [[Deividas Matulionis]], Lithuania ambassador in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beniušis|first1=Vaidotas|title=Vokietija viešai parodė rastą Vasario 16-osios aktą, patvirtino, kad tai – originalas|url=http://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/vokietija-viesai-parode-rasta-vasario-16-osios-akta-patvirtino-kad-tai-originalas-56-776650|website=15min.lt|accessdate=30 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330151446/http://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/vokietija-viesai-parode-rasta-vasario-16-osios-akta-patvirtino-kad-tai-originalas-56-776650|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Lithuania finds lost declaration of independence|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/30/lithuania-finds-lost-declaration-independence-1918-centenary-german-archive|website=The Guardian|accessdate=30 March 2017|date=30 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330165033/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/30/lithuania-finds-lost-declaration-independence-1918-centenary-german-archive|archivedate=30 March 2017|df=}}</ref> On 5 October 2017, Lithuania Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Linas Antanas Linkevičius|Linas Linkevičius]] and Germany Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Sigmar Gabriel]] signed an agreement that the original Act of Independence will be displayed for five years in the [[House of the Signatories]] where it was originally signed, making it the main symbol of the Lithuania's Centenary of the Restoration of the State celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jakučionis|first1=Saulius|title=Lietuvos ir Vokietijos ministrai pasirašė sutartį dėl Vasario 16-osios akto perdavimo|url=https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/lietuvos-ir-vokietijos-ministrai-pasirase-sutarti-del-vasario-16-osios-akto-perdavimo-56-862934|website=15min.lt|accessdate=5 October 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005125450/https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/lietuvos-ir-vokietijos-ministrai-pasirase-sutarti-del-vasario-16-osios-akto-perdavimo-56-862934|archivedate=5 October 2017|df=}}</ref> On 22 December 2017, experts from the [[Law enforcement in Lithuania|Lithuanian Police]] Forensic Research Center after a thorough analysis announced that the hand-written act was written by one of the signatories [[Jurgis Šaulys]] hand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Policijos ekspertų tyrimas: Nepriklausomybės aktą surašė signataras Jurgis Šaulys|url=https://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/policijos-ekspertu-tyrimas-nepriklausomybes-akta-surase-signataras-jurgis-saulys.d?id=76721919|website=[[DELFI]]|accessdate=22 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223042954/https://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/policijos-ekspertu-tyrimas-nepriklausomybes-akta-surase-signataras-jurgis-saulys.d?id=76721919|archivedate=23 December 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jačauskas|first1=Ignas|title=Signataro Jurgio Šaulio rašyseną Vasario 16-osios akte išdavė išskirtiniai požymiai|url=https://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/signataro-jurgio-saulio-rasysena-vasario-16-osios-akte-isdave-isskirtiniai-pozymiai.d?id=76725235|website=[[DELFI]]|accessdate=22 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222155235/https://www.delfi.lt/news/daily/lithuania/signataro-jurgio-saulio-rasysena-vasario-16-osios-akte-isdave-isskirtiniai-pozymiai.d?id=76725235|archivedate=22 December 2017|df=}}</ref>
On 22 December 2017, yet another version of the Act of Independence of Lithuania was found by historian [[Darius Antanavičius]] in the [[Vatican Secret Archives]] that was sent to the [[Holy See]]. This version of the Act was printed in [[German language]] and signed by [[Antanas Smetona]], [[Jonas Vileišis]], Jurgis Šaulys and [[Justinas Staugaitis]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Vatikano archyve istorikas Darius Antanavičius rado Vasario 16-osios akto vertimą į vokiečių kalbą|url=https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/vatikano-archyve-rastas-vasario-16-osios-akto-vertimas-i-vokieciu-kalba-56-901366|website=[[15min.lt]]|accessdate=22 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222182352/https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/vatikano-archyve-rastas-vasario-16-osios-akto-vertimas-i-vokieciu-kalba-56-901366|archivedate=22 December 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jakilaitis|first1=Edmundas|title=Istorikas A.Kasperavičius: tokių atradimų laukia dar ne vienas|url=https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/istorikas-a-kasperavicius-tokiu-atradimu-laukia-dar-ne-vienas-56-901472|website=[[15min.lt]] / Dėmesio centre|accessdate=23 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223112419/https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/istorikas-a-kasperavicius-tokiu-atradimu-laukia-dar-ne-vienas-56-901472|archivedate=23 December 2017|df=}}</ref>
===The signatories=== {{Main|Signatories of the Act of Independence of Lithuania}} Most of the signatories of the Act remained active in the cultural and political life of independent Lithuania. [[Jonas Vileišis]] served in the [[Seimas]] and as [[mayor]] of [[Kaunas]], [[temporary capital of Lithuania]];<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Vileišis, Jonas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = VI | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages = 124–125}}</ref> [[Saliamonas Banaitis]] was involved in finance, opening several banks.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Banaitis, Saliamonas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = I | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages = 282}}</ref> Among the signatories were two future Presidents of Lithuania, [[Antanas Smetona]] and [[Aleksandras Stulginskis]]. [[Jonas Basanavičius]], chairman of the Council of Lithuania, returned to an academic life, pursuing his research in Lithuanian culture and folklore.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Basanavičius, Jonas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = I | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =307–310}}</ref> Five signatories died before [[World War II]] started; three died during the [[Nazi occupation of Lithuania|Nazi occupation]]. Those who did not emigrate to Western countries became [[political prisoner]]s after Lithuania was occupied by the Soviet Union.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.vilnensis.vu.lt/nr-17/signatar.html |title=Vasario 16-osios Akto signatarai |first=Sigitas |last=Jegelavičius |journal=Universitas Vilnensis |publisher=[[Vilnius University]] |date=February 2002 |issue=17 |issn=1822-1513 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070128041835/http://www.vilnensis.vu.lt/nr-17/signatar.html |archivedate=2007-01-28 |language=Lithuanian}}</ref>
[[Aleksandras Stulginskis]] and [[Petras Klimas]] were sent to prison in [[Siberia]] by Soviet authorities, but survived and returned to Lithuania;<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Klimas, Petras | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = III | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =142–143}}</ref> [[Pranas Dovydaitis]] and [[Vladas Mironas]] were also sent to Siberia but died there.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Dovydaitis, Pranas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = II | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =101–103}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Mironas, Vladas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = III | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =545–546}}</ref> [[Kazys Bizauskas]] disappeared during the summer of 1941 while being transported to a Soviet prison in [[Minsk]]; he is presumed to have been shot along with a number of other prisoners.<ref name=Bizauskas>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Bizauskas, Kazimieras | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = I | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =372–373}}</ref> [[Donatas Malinauskas]] was [[June deportation|deported to Russia]] on 14 June 1941.<ref name=Malinauskas>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Malinauskas, Donatas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = III | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =459–460}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lnm.lt/ekspoziciniai-padaliniai/signataru-namai/lietuvos-nepriklausomybes-akto-signatarai/129.html?task=view |title=Donatas Malinauskas (1869–1942) |accessdate=2014-10-11 |publisher=[[National Museum of Lithuania]] |language=Lithuanian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517184241/http://www.lnm.lt/ekspoziciniai-padaliniai/signataru-namai/lietuvos-nepriklausomybes-akto-signatarai/129.html?task=view |archivedate=2011-05-17 |df= }}</ref>
Several of the surviving signatories emigrated. [[Jurgis Šaulys]] and [[Kazimieras Steponas Šaulys]] died in [[Switzerland]].<ref name=Bizauskas /><ref name=Malinauskas /> [[Antanas Smetona]], [[Mykolas Biržiška]], and [[Steponas Kairys]] emigrated to the [[United States]] and are buried there.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Smetona, Antanas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = V | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages =231–235}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Biržiška, Mykolas | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = I | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages= 364–365}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Simas Sužiedėlis | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia Lituanica]] | title = Steponas Kairys | year = 1970–1978 | publisher = Juozas Kapočius | volume = III | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = {{LCC|74-114275}} | pages= 17–19}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:House of Signatories.jpg|thumb|left|220 px|The [[House of the Signatories]] on 16 February 2007]] The Act of 16 February proclaimed the ''re''-establishment (''atstatyti'') of the Lithuanian state, making it the successor to the Lithuanian historical state, the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]].<ref name=VL>{{cite web|url=http://www.lrs.lt/sventes/980216/vas16mod.htm |title=Vasario 16-oji – modernios Lietuvos valstybės atkūrimo simbolis ir pamatas |accessdate=2007-01-31 |first=Vytautas |last=Landsbergis |authorlink=Vytautas Landsbergis |publisher=[[Seimas]] |date=1998-02-16 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tsfVcI4E?url=http://www.lrs.lt/sventes/980216/vas16mod.htm |archivedate=2010-10-31 |language=lt |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In this respect the Council deviated from the resolution adopted by the Vilnius Conference which called for establishment (''sudaryti'') of a Lithuanian state.<ref name=maks /> However, it was made clear that the new state would be quite different from the old Duchy: it was to be organized only in ethnic Lithuanian lands (except for the [[Vilnius region]] which was majority Polish) and was to be governed by democratic principles,<ref name=maks /> as opposed to the multi-ethnic Duchy that had been ruled by aristocracy. The termination of the ties binding Lithuania to other states was addressed to Germany, Russia, and Poland, all of which had their own plans for the country.<ref name=Lina /><ref name=VL /> Even though not addressed directly, the Act renounced any attempt to resurrect the former [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth|Polish-Lithuanian union]].<ref name=Skirius />
The Act of 16 February 1918, is the legal basis for the existence of present-day Lithuania, both during the [[interwar period]] and since 1990.<ref name=maks /> The Act became one of the key elements during the restoration of Lithuania's independence from the Soviet Union in 1990.<ref name=LRS>{{cite web|url=http://www3.lrs.lt/seimu_istorija/w3_viewer.ViewTheme-p_int_tv_id=281&p_kalb_id=2&p_org=0.htm |title=Supreme Council – Reconstituent Seimas 1990–1992| accessdate=2007-01-30| publisher=Seimas| year=2002 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tsfZeOma?url=http://www3.lrs.lt/seimu_istorija/w3_viewer.ViewTheme-p_int_tv_id%3D281%26p_kalb_id%3D2%26p_org%3D0.htm |archivedate=2010-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Žalimas |first=Dainius |editor=Ineta Ziemele |chapter=Legal Issues on the Continuity of the Republic of Lithuania |title=Baltic Yearbook of International Law |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iGLp7QEelbIC&pg=PA9 |year=2002 |volume=1 |publisher=Kluwer Law International |page=9 |isbn=90-411-1736-9 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610121329/https://books.google.com/books?id=iGLp7QEelbIC&pg=PA9 |archivedate=2016-06-10 |df= }}</ref> A paragraph in the [[Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania]], delivered on 11 March 1990, stated:<ref name=LRS /> {{quote| The Act of Independence of 16 February 1918 of the Council of Lithuania and the Constituent Assembly (Seimas) decree of 15 May 1920 on the re-established democratic State of Lithuania never lost their legal effect and comprise the constitutional foundation of the State of Lithuania.}}
This formulation emphasized the continuity of the two legal Acts. The Act of 16 February 1918, and its successor, the Act of 11 March 1990, are regarded as two of the most important developments of Lithuanian society in the 20th century.<ref name=VAR>{{cite journal|url=http://www.voruta.lt/vasario-16-osios-akto-reiksme-lietuviu-tautos-politinei-raidai-2/|title=Vasario 16-osios Akto reikšmė lietuvių tautos politinei raidai|accessdate=2007-01-30|first=Antanas|last=Tyla|journal=[[Voruta (newspaper)|Voruta]]|date=2005-03-06|issn=1392-0677|language=lt|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906223930/http://www.voruta.lt/vasario-16-osios-akto-reiksme-lietuviu-tautos-politinei-raidai-2/|archivedate=2014-09-06|df=}}</ref>
16 February in Lithuania is an official holiday.<ref>{{lt icon}} [http://www3.lrs.lt/pls/inter3/dokpaieska.showdoc_l?p_id=134377 Lietuvos Respublikos švenčių dienų įstatymas], Žin., 1990, Nr. 31-757. Seimas (2001-05-24). Retrieved on 2007-02-07.</ref> On this day various ceremonies are hosted all across Lithuania. The 2014 commemoration included laying flowers at the signatories’ graves in [[Rasos Cemetery]], awarding the [[Lithuanian National Prize]], the hoisting of the three [[Baltic States]]’s flags at [[Daukantas Square]], dedicated concerts at [[Cathedral Square, Vilnius|Cathedral Square in Vilnius]] and at the [[Lithuanian National Philharmonic Society]] hall, and the lighting of 16 fires along [[Gediminas Avenue]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.lrs.lt/pls/inter/w5_show?p_r=5691&p_k=1&p_d=144500|title=2014 metų Lietuvos valstybės atkūrimo dienos minėjimo renginių programa|publisher=[[Seimas]] (Parliament of Lithuania)|accessdate=2014-10-11|language=lt}}</ref>
In 1992, an award was established in honor of Jonas Basanavičius, who led the Council of Lithuania when the Act of 16 February was signed. The Jonas Basanavičius Prize is bestowed for distinguished work within the previous five years in the fields of ethnic and cultural studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whatson.delfi.lt/archive/article.php?id=8031858 |title=J.Basanavičiaus premija šiemet skirta mokslo istorikui L.Klimkai| accessdate=2007-02-07| publisher=[[Delfi.lt]] and [[Baltic News Service|BNS]]| date=2005-11-21|language=lt}}</ref>

'''Adjusted Peak Performance''' (APP) is a metric introduced by the [[U.S. Department of Commerce]]'s [[Bureau of Industry and Security]] (BIS) to more accurately predict the suitability of a computing system to complex computational problems, specifically those used in simulating [[nuclear weapons]]. This is used to determine the export limitations placed on certain computer systems under the [[Export Administration Regulations]] 15 CFR.
The (simplified) algorithm used to calculate APP consists of the following steps:
* Determine how many 64 bit (or better) floating point operations every processor in the system can perform per clock cycle (best case). This is FPO(i). * Determine the clock frequency of every processor. This is F(i). * Choose the weighting factor for each processor: 0.9 for vector processors and 0.3 for non-vector processors. This is W(i). * Calculate the APP for the system as follows: APP = FPO(1) * F(1) * W(1) + ... + FPO(n) * F(n) * W(n).
The metric was introduced in April 2006 to replace the Composite Theoretical Performance (CTP) metric which was introduced in 1993. APP was itself replaced in November 2007 when the BIS amended 15 CFR to include the December 2006 [[Wassenaar Arrangement]] Plenary Agreement Implementation's new metric - [[FLOPS|Gigaflops]] (GFLOPS), one billion floating point operations per second, or TeraFLOPS, one trillion floating point operations per second.
The unit of measurement is Weighted TeraFLOPS (WT) to specify Adjusted Peak Performance (APP).
The weighting factor is 0.3 for non-vector processors and 0.9 for vector processors. For example, a PowerPC 750 running at 800MHz would be rated at 0.00024 WT due to being able to execute one floating point instruction per cycle and not having a vector unit. Note that only 64 bit (or wider) floating point instructions count.
Notes:
* Processors without 64 bit (or better) floating point support have an FPO of zero. * The current APP limit is 0.75 WT. * Use the document referenced below (or an updated version) if you need to calculate APP for export purposes. It holds more details and a number of clarifications and exceptions. Also consult a lawyer who specializes in these things.
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110811050143/http://www.bis.doc.gov/hpcs/default.htm U. S. Bureau of Industry and Security—High Performance Computers (HPCs)] * [http://www.intel.com/support/processors/sb/CS-017346.htm Intel's microprocessor export compliance metrics] * [http://www.oracle.com/us/products/export/eccn-matrix-hardware-412043.pdf APP values for Oracle systems]

{{Infobox museum |name = ''Alte Nationalgalerie'' (Old National Gallery) |image = Alte Nationalgalerie abends (Zuschnitt).jpg |imagesize = 300px | map_type = Germany Berlin central#Germany |coordinates = {{coord|52|31|15|N|13|23|53|E|region:DE-BE_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |established = 1861 |location = Bodestrasse 1-3 ([[Museum Island]])
Berlin, Berlin D-10178 Germany |type = [[Art]]{{citation |title=Alte Nationalgalerie: About |publisher=ARTINFO |year=2008 |url=http://www.artinfo.com/galleryguide/13398/1909/about/alte-nationalgalerie-berlin/ |accessdate=2008-07-24}} |visitors = |director = |curator = |publictransit = |website = [https://www.smb.museum/en/museums-institutions/alte-nationalgalerie/home.html Alte Nationalgalerie] {{en icon}} }} The '''Alte Nationalgalerie''' (Old National Gallery) in [[Berlin]] is an [[art gallery]] showing a collection of [[Neoclassicism#Painting and printmaking|Neoclassical]], [[Romanticism#Romantic visual arts|Romantic]], [[Biedermeier#Visual arts|Biedermeier]], [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] and early [[Modernism|Modernist]] artwork, part of the [[National Gallery (Berlin)|Berlin National Gallery]], which in turn is part of the [[Staatliche Museen zu Berlin]]. It is the original building of the National Gallery, whose holdings are now housed in several additional buildings. It is situated on [[Museum Island]], a [[UNESCO]]-designated [[World Heritage site]]. == History == === Founding === The first impetus to founding a national gallery came in 1815. The idea gained momentum during the 1830s, but without an actual building. In 1841 the first real plans were created. These plans never made it out of the planning stages, but finally in 1861 the [[National Gallery (Berlin)|National Gallery]] was founded, after banker [[Johann Heinrich Wagener]] donated 262 paintings by both German and foreign artists. This donation formed the basis of the current collection. The collection was first known as ''Wagenersche und Nationalgalerie'' (Wagener and National Gallery) and was housed in the buildings of the [[Akademie der Künste]]. The current building, shaped like a Roman [[temple]] with an appended [[apse]], was designed by [[Friedrich August Stüler]] and after his death, realised in detail under [[Carl Busse (architect)|Carl Busse]]. === Building and related developments === [[Image:BerlinNationalgalerie.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Picture of the Alte Nationalgalerie from [[Heinrich August Pierer]]'s ''Universal-Lexikon'', 1891.]] [[Friedrich August Stüler]] began working on a design for the building in 1863, based on a sketch by King [[Frederick William IV of Prussia]].Claude Keisch, ''The Alte Nationalgalerie, Berlin'', London: Scala / Munich: Beck, 2005, {{ISBN|9783406526756}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ApOj7UXAPkYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Nationalgalerie+Berlin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MlPLT_yKN4To2QX8oZnaCw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=based%20on%20a%20sketch%20by%20the%20king&f=false p. 7]. Two years and two failed plans later, his third proposal was finally accepted. Stüler died before planning was completed and [[Carl Busse (architect)|Carl Busse]] handled the remaining details in 1865. In 1866, by order of the king and his [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]], the ''Kommission für den Bau der Nationalgalerie'' (Commission for the construction of the national gallery) was created. Ground was broken in 1867 under the supervision of [[Heinrich Strack]]. In 1872 the structure was completed and interior work began. The opening took place on March 22, 1876 in the presence of the Kaiser. Because of the building's modern construction using brick and iron, it was widely believed to be fireproof. The exterior and outer staircase were constructed of [[Triassic]] sandstone from [[Nebra (Unstrut)|Nebra]]. At the opening the collection was still relatively small. Next to Wagener's collection, originally, was a display of [[Cartoon#Fine art|cartoon]]s by [[Peter von Cornelius]] that had been bequeathed to the Prussian government. The initial objective of the gallery was to collect contemporary, primarily Prussian art, as Berlin did not then have any repository of modern art. In 1874 Max Jordan became the first director of the National Gallery. In 1896 he was succeeded by [[Hugo von Tschudi]], who acquired [[Impressionism|Impressionist]] works, risking conflict with the Kaiser because this ended the collection's focus on German art. The German National Gallery thus became the most important museum for modern French Art at the turn of the century.Philipp Demandt: „Schule des Sehens“. Die Nationalgalerie und die Moderne, in: Angelika Wesenberg (Hg.), Impressionismus – Expressionismus. Kunstwende, Berlin 2015, pp 13-19. === 20th century === In 1909, [[Ludwig Justi]] assumed the post of director, and added [[Expressionism|Expressionist]] works to the collection. Following the [[German Revolution of 1918–19]] that ended Imperial rule, he moved the modern art to the [[Kronprinzenpalais]] at the end of [[Unter den Linden]], which became known as ''National Gallery II''. In 1933, the new [[Nazi Germany|Nazi authorities]] dismissed Justi, who was followed by [[Eberhard Hanfstaengl]]. He remained until 1937, when he too was dismissed. His successor, [[Paul Ortwin Rave]], remained until 1950, although because of World War II the building was closed during much of that time. It was heavily damaged in Allied air raids. It was partly reopened in 1949, but reconstruction continued until 1969. Between 1998 and 2001, the museum was renovated thoroughly by German architect [[HG Merz]]. Some extra halls were added on the uppermost floor and now contain the [[Romanticism|Romantic]] works. The three-year, $62 million renovation of the Alte Nationalgalerie was part of a refurbishment of [[Museum Island]] and the energetic effort by government and private institutions to re-establish Berlin as Germany's political and cultural heart.Desmond Butler (December 2, 2001), [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/02/world/berlin-museum-s-revival-bolsters-german-identity.html Berlin Museum's Revival Bolsters German Identity] ''[[The New York Times]]''. ==Architecture== The Alte Nationalgalerie, together with the [[Altes Museum]], the [[Neues Museum]], the [[Bode Museum]], the [[Pergamon Museum]], the [[Berlin Cathedral]] and the [[Lustgarten]], make up the [[Museum Island]] complex in Berlin. It is situated in the middle of the island, between the rails of the [[Berlin Stadtbahn]] and Bode Street on the eastern banks. It is connected to the Pergamon Museum to the north, and to the Neues Museum, the Altes Museum, and the Berlin Cathedral to the south. The building was designed by [[Friedrich August Stüler]] with details by [[Carl Busse (architect)|Carl Busse]], in an architectural style that is a mix between late Classicism and early [[Neo-Renaissance]], and realised by [[Heinrich Strack]]. It was intended to express "the unity of art, nation, and history", and therefore has aspects reminiscent of a church (an apse) and a theatre (the grand staircase) as well as a temple. An equestrian statue of Frederick William IV tops the stairs, and the inside stairs have a frieze by [[Otto Geyer]] depicting German history from prehistoric times to the 19th century. The exterior of the building still retains its original appearance, whereas the interior has been renovated many times in order to suit the exhibits.Keisch, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ApOj7UXAPkYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Nationalgalerie+Berlin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MlPLT_yKN4To2QX8oZnaCw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=seen%20as%20sacrifices%20to%20function&f=false p. 8]. == Collection == The collection contains works of the [[Neoclassicism#Painting and printmaking|Neoclassical]] and [[Romanticism#Romantic visual arts|Romantic]] movements (by artists such as [[Caspar David Friedrich]], [[Karl Friedrich Schinkel]], and [[Karl Blechen]]), of the [[Biedermeier#Visual arts|Biedermeier]], French [[Impressionism]] (such as [[Édouard Manet]] and [[Claude Monet]]) and early [[Modernism]] (including [[Adolph von Menzel]], [[Max Liebermann]] and [[Lovis Corinth]]). Among the most important exhibits are Friedrich's ''[[The Monk by the Sea|Der Mönch am Meer]]'' (The Monk by the Sea), von Menzel's ''Eisenwalzwerk'' (The Iron Rolling Mill) and sculptor [[Johann Gottfried Schadow]]'s ''Prinzessinnengruppe'', a double statue of princesses [[Louise of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]] and [[Frederica of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Frederica of Prussia]]. The Alte Nationalgalerie houses one of the largest collections of 19th-century sculptures and paintings in Germany. ==Gallery== File:Adolf Friedrich Erdmann von Menzel 021.jpg|''Eisenwalzwerk'' (The Iron Rolling Mill (Modern Cyclopes)), [[Adolph von Menzel]], 1875 File:Theodor Hildebrandt Krieger u Kind.jpg| ''The Warrior and his Child'', [[Theodor Hildebrandt]], 1832 File:Charles Landseer Cromwell Battle of Naseby.JPG| ''Cromwell in [[Battle of Naseby]]'', [[Charles Landseer]], 1851 File:1829 Hildebrandt Raeuber anagoria.JPG| ''The Robber'', [[Theodor Hildebrandt]], 1829 File:1836 Heimkehr des Palikaren anagoria.JPG| ''Return of the Palikar'', [[Eduard Magnus]], 1836 File:Johann Erdmann Hummel Schachpartie.jpg| ''Chess Game'', [[Johann Erdmann Hummel]], 1819 File:Josef Danhauser Liszt am Flügel 1840 01.jpg| ''Liszt at the Piano'', [[Josef Danhauser]], 1819 File:Hussitenpredigt.jpg| ''Hussite Sermon'', [[Karl Friedrich Lessing]], 1836 File:Anton von Werner - Im Etappenquartier vor Paris - Google Art Project.jpg| ''In the Troops' Quarters outside Paris'', [[Anton von Werner]], 1894 File:1804 Wächter Telemachs Rückkehr anagoria.JPG| ''Telemachus' Return'', Eberhard von Wächter, 1804 File:1865 Steffeck Rechtsanwalt Ernst Lau anagoria.JPG| ''Portrait of the Advocate Ernst Lau'', [[Carl Steffeck]], 1865 File:Dahl Fjord b Holmestrand.JPG| ''Fjord at Holmestrand'', [[Johan Christian Dahl]], 1843 File:Caspar David Friedrich - Mondaufgang am Meer - Google Art Project.jpg| ''[[Moonrise by the Sea|Moonrise at the Ocean]]'', [[Caspar David Friedrich]], 1822 == See also == * [[List of art museums]] * [[Berlin Museums|List of museums in Berlin]] * [[List of museums in Germany]] * [[Neue Nationalgalerie]] == References == {{reflist}} * ''This article is based on a translation of the German Wikipedia article [[:de:Alte Nationalgalerie|Alte Nationalgalerie]].'' == Further reading == * [[Bernhard Maaz]] (Ed.). ''Die Alte Nationalgalerie. Geschichte, Bau und Umbau.'' Berlin: G + H, 2001, {{ISBN|9783886094530}}. * Peter-Klaus Schuster. ''Die Alte Nationalgalerie.'' Berlin: SMB-DuMont, 2003, {{ISBN|9783832173708}}. * Angelika Wesenberg (Ed.). ''Frankreich in der Nationalgalerie: Courbet, Manet, Cézanne, Renoir, Rodin.'' Exhibition catalog. Berlin: Nationalgalerie, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-88609-585-8}}. * Bénédicte Savoy & Philippa Sissis (Hrsg.): ''Die Berliner Museumsinsel: Impressionen internationaler Besucher (1830-1990). Eine Anthologie.'' Böhlau, Wien/Köln/Weimar 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-412-20991-9}}. == External links == {{Commons category|Alte Nationalgalerie}} *{{en icon}} [http://www.smb.museum/en/museums-institutions/alte-nationalgalerie/home.html Alte Nationalgalerie] *[http://www.panorama-cities.net/berlin/museum_island.html 360° Panorama at the Alte Nationalgalerie] *[http://en.gallerix.ru/album/Alte-Nationalgalerie Some paintings from museum collection] {{Museum Island, Berlin}} {{Visitor attractions in Berlin}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Berlin]] [[Category:Museum Island]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1861]] [[Category:1861 establishments in Prussia]] [[Category:Berlin State Museums]]

{{Infobox film | name = Being John Malkovich | image = Being John Malkovich poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Spike Jonze]] | producer = [[Michael Stipe]]
[[Sandy Stern]]
[[Steve Golin]]
[[Vincent Landay]] | writer = [[Charlie Kaufman]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[John Cusack]] * [[Cameron Diaz]] * [[Catherine Keener]] * [[Orson Bean]] * [[Mary Kay Place]] * [[John Malkovich]]}} | music = [[Carter Burwell]] | cinematography = [[Lance Acord]] | editing = [[Eric Zumbrunnen]] | studio = [[Gramercy Pictures]]
[[Propaganda Films]]
Single Cell Pictures | distributor = [[USA Films]] | released = {{Film date|1999|9|2|[[56th Venice International Film Festival|Venice]]|1999|10|29|United States}} | runtime = 112 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $13 million | gross = $32.4 million }} '''''Being John Malkovich''''' is a 1999 American [[fantasy film|fantasy]] [[comedy-drama]] film directed by [[Spike Jonze]] and written by [[Charlie Kaufman]], both making their feature film debut. The film stars [[John Cusack]], [[Cameron Diaz]], and [[Catherine Keener]], with [[John Malkovich]] and [[Charlie Sheen]] as themselves. The film follows a puppeteer who finds a portal that leads into Malkovich's mind. Released by [[USA Films]], the film was nominated in three categories at the [[72nd Academy Awards]]: [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] for Jonze, [[Best Original Screenplay]] for Kaufman and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] for Keener. == Plot == Craig Schwartz is an unemployed puppeteer in a forlorn marriage with his pet-obsessed wife Lotte. Gaining a file clerk job through Dr. Lester at LesterCorp, in the strange Floor {{frac|7|1|2}} low-ceiling offices of the Mertin-Flemmer Building in New York City, he develops an attraction to his coworker Maxine Lund, who does not return his affections. Craig discovers and enters a small door hidden behind a filing cabinet, and crawls down a tunnel. Suddenly he is quickly drawn into the opposite end of the tunnel, and finds himself in the mind of actor [[John Malkovich]]. Craig is able to observe and sense whatever Malkovich does for fifteen minutes before he is ejected and dropped into a ditch near the [[New Jersey Turnpike]]. He reveals the portal to Maxine, who sees the profit in it, and they let others use it for $200 a turn. Craig tells Lotte, who becomes obsessed with the experience, which had allowed her to live out her [[transgender]] desires. Lotte becomes attracted to Maxine when she is experiencing Malkovich, and she and Malkovich begin a sexual relationship with Lotte inside Malkovich's head while Maxine and Malkovich have sex. Craig, forsaken by both women, binds and gags Lotte and locks her in a cage with the chimpanzee, then enters Malkovich's mind and has sex with Maxine. Soon Craig, with his expert puppeteer skills, discovers that he is able to control Malkovich's actions while in his head. This causes the actor to feel paranoid that he is being controlled by someone else. After Malkovich consults with his friend [[Charlie Sheen]], Malkovich trails Maxine to the Mertin-Flemmer building, where he himself tries the portal into his own head. He finds himself in a world where everyone has his face and they only say "Malkovich", and views his own lifetime history. He is then ejected and meets Craig by the turnpike. Malkovich demands that the portal be closed, but Craig refuses. Lotte escapes with the help of her pet chimpanzee, who learned how to untie knots in Africa during a zoological capture, which is shown viewed from the chimpanzee's point of view. Lotte phones Maxine, revealing that it was Craig having sex with her while inside Malkovich. Maxine is annoyed but accepts it, because she enjoyed the experience. Seeking help, Lotte finds Lester, who reveals himself to be Captain Mertin, the original founder of LesterCorp. Lester is aware of the portal, and has a room dedicated to Malkovich's life. Lester explains that the person who is connected to the portal becomes "ripe" for lasting occupation by others on the eve of their 44th birthday. However, when the host turns 44, the portal immediately moves to its next host, an unborn child. If it is possible for a person to take advantage of the "ripe" host and enter the portal then, one can greatly increase one's lifespan, and then one can eventually move on to another host. However, if one misses the brief window of "ripeness", and enters the portal even a minute too late, one will find oneself trapped within the unborn child who will be the next host. Lester, who has been using the portal in order to prolong his life, reveals his plan to use Malkovich when "ripe" as the host for him and several of his elderly friends. Offered the chance to join Lester's group, Lotte warns him that Craig currently has control of Malkovich. Craig finds he is able to remain in Malkovich indefinitely. He spends the next eight months in Malkovich's body, and using his puppeteer's control, he is able to turn Malkovich into a world-class puppeteer. Malkovich marries Maxine. He learns that she is pregnant as their relationship grows distant. As Malkovich's 44th birthday approaches, Lester and his friends cut a deal with Maxine, and fake her kidnapping. They call up Craig, threatening to kill her if Craig does not leave Malkovich. Craig ends the call, causing Lester to think that he is calling their bluff. Lotte loses hope and attempts to kill Maxine, but they end up at the turnpike after falling through the portal and through Malkovich's shame-ridden subconscious. Maxine reveals to Lotte that Maxine conceived when Lotte was inside Malkovich's body, and she kept the child because it is "theirs". The revelation cements their love for each other. Craig calls Lester back, thinking Maxine is still in danger. Realizing his opportunity, Lester continues his bluff, convincing Craig to leave Malkovich's body. Lester and his friends enter the portal, taking control of Malkovich. Craig, discovering that Lotte and Maxine are together again, decides to enter the portal to become Malkovich and regain Maxine, however he has unknowingly missed the deadline for getting into Malkovich. Years later, an aging Malkovich, containing the collective mind of Lester and his friends, reveals to Sheen a plan to prolong their lives via Maxine's daughter Emily, within whom Craig is now permanently trapped. Through Emily's eyes Craig is forced to watch Maxine and Lotte living happily together as he futilely pleads that Emily look away. == Cast == {{Cast listing| * [[John Cusack]] as Craig Schwartz * [[Cameron Diaz]] as Lotte Schwartz * [[Catherine Keener]] as Maxine Lund * [[John Malkovich]] as John Horatio Malkovich * [[Orson Bean]] as Dr. Lester * [[Mary Kay Place]] as Floris * [[Charlie Sheen]] as himself * [[W. Earl Brown]] as First J.M. Inc. Customer * [[Carlos Jacott]] as Larry the Agent * [[Willie Garson]] as Guy in Restaurant * [[Byrne Piven]] as Captain James Mertin }} == Production == === Development === Kaufman's idea of ''Being John Malkovich'' originated simply as "a story about a man who falls in love with someone who is not his wife." Gradually he added further elements to the story which he found entertaining, such as floor 7½ of the Mertin Flemmer building; among his first ideas, Malkovich was "nowhere to be seen". He wrote the script [[Spec script|on spec]] in 1994 and though it was widely read by [[production company]] and [[film studio]] executives, all turned it down. Hoping to find a producer, Kaufman sent the script to Francis Ford Coppola, who passed it on to his then-son-in-law Spike Jonze.{{cite web |title=''Being John Malkovich'' a quirky wonder |work=[[Arizona Daily Star]] |url=http://azstarnet.com/entertainment/movies/article_ee681184-48ef-558a-956f-8f431ab4dc0c.html |first=Phil |last=Villarreal |date=January 7, 2007 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} Jonze first read the script in 1996 and had agreed to direct the film by 1997. Jonze brought the script to [[Propaganda Films]], which agreed to produce the film in partnership with production company Single Cell Pictures. Single Cell producers [[Michael Stipe]] and [[Sandy Stern]] pitched the film to numerous studios, including [[New Line Cinema]], who dropped the project after chairman [[Robert Shaye]] asked: "Why the fuck can't it be ''Being [[Tom Cruise]]''?". Jonze revealed in a September 2013 interview that Malkovich asked him the same question during their first meeting and also relayed Malkovich's attitude after filming commenced: {{quote|Either the movie's a bomb and it's got not only my name above the title but my name in the title, so I'm fucked that way; or it does well and I'm just forever associated with this character.{{cite news |title=Spike Jonze on letting ''Her'' rip and ''Being John Malkovich'' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/sep/09/spike-jonze-her-scarlett-johansson |accessdate=September 13, 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=September 9, 2013 |first=Chris |last=Michael}}}} Jonze explained in the same interview that he didn't realize how brave Malkovich's performance in the film was. With a budget of $10 million,{{cite web |title=The Write Stuff: Sea change for scribe's future |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117801689.html |first=Jonathan |last=Bing |date=June 19, 2001 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} [[principal photography]] of ''Being John Malkovich'' began on July 20, 1998, and continued through August.{{cite web |title=Bean, Place in ''Malkovich'' |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117479351.html |first=Benedict |last=Carver |date=August 10, 1998 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} Filming took place primarily in [[Los Angeles]]; specific locations included the [[University of Southern California]] campus and the Observation Bar on board the [[RMS Queen Mary|RMS ''Queen Mary'']].{{cite web |title=Campuses a favorite locale for filming |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/sep/12/local/me-125locations12 |first=Steve |last=Padilla |date=September 12, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}}{{cite web |title=The Queen Mary: Location Filming |work=[[RMS Queen Mary|QueenMary.com]] |url=http://www.queenmary.com/Filming-Locations.aspx |accessdate=November 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101126200422/http://queenmary.com/Filming-Locations.aspx |archivedate=November 26, 2010 |deadurl=no}} The puppets in the film were created by Kamela Portuges and Images in Motion. Phillip Huber animated the puppets.{{cite web |last=Meltzer |first=Steve |title=Marionettes In Hollywood |url=http://www.hubermarionettes.com/bjm/bjminterview.html |work=Puppetry Journal |publisher=HuberMarionettes.com |accessdate=May 25, 2014}} ===Casting=== Diaz's [[make-up artist]] Gucci Westman described styling Diaz in the role as "a challenge, to make her look homely."{{cite web |title=5 Minutes with Gucci Westman |work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue Australia]] |url=http://www.vogue.com.au/beauty/five+minutes+with/5+minutes+with+gucci+westman,2819 |first=Sigourney |last=Cantelo |date=March 11, 2010 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} The script included minimal physical descriptions of characters, and thus when Diaz took up the role she did not know that "people weren't going to recognize me."{{cite web |title=Cameron Diaz and Catherine Keener |work=CrankyCritic.com |url=http://www.crankycritic.com/qa/diaz_keener.html |first=Paul |last=Fischer |accessdate=November 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107062624/http://www.crankycritic.com/qa/diaz_keener.html |archivedate=January 7, 2010 |df= }} Cusack read the film's script after he had asked his [[Talent agent|agent]] to present him with the "craziest, most unproduceable script you can find." Impressed with the script, he asked his agent to follow its progress and book him an audition, with which he won the role.{{cite web |title=John Cusack |work=[[The A.V. Club]] |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/john-cusack,14181 |first=Tasha |last=Robinson |date=December 27, 2007 |accessdate=November 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112002211/http://www.avclub.com/articles/john-cusack%2C14181 |archivedate=November 12, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }} Keener cited ''Being John Malkovich'' as an instance of her taking up a role based on the director's previous work. She had heard about Jonze's experience with [[music video]]s and took up the part of Maxine although she initially disliked the character and did not feel that she was right for the part.{{cite web |title=Being Catherine Keener |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/27/style/tmagazine/t_w_1595_1597_well_keener_.html |first=Lynn |last=Hirschberg |date=August 27, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} {{cite web |title=Being John Malkovich |work=[[DVD Verdict]] |url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/beingjohnm.php |first=Mike |last=Jackson |date=May 5, 2000 |accessdate=November 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101011221148/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/beingjohnm.php |archivedate=October 11, 2010 |deadurl=no}} She was subsequently nominated for an Oscar. [[Charlie Kaufman]] said that there was never another actor in Malkovich's place in the script: "The screenplay was always "Being John Malkovich", even before I had any expectation that John Malkovich would even read the script."{{cite web |title=Charlie Kaufman |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117792734 |first=Robert |last=Holfer |date=September 14, 1999 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} He chose Malkovich because he believed there to be "an enigmatic quality about him that works",{{cite web |title=Mike Leigh interview, and ''Being John Malkovich'' premiere |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/1999/nov/10/mikeleigh |date=November 10, 1999 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} though Malkovich was partly chosen because of the sound of his name in repetition. Kaufman explained that "When we were thinking of alternatives, we found that a lot of them weren't fun to say."{{cite web |title=Being Charlie Kaufman |work=[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]] |url=http://www.salon.com/ent/col/srag/1999/11/11/kaufman/print.html |first=Michael |last=Sragow |date=November 11, 1999 |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} Jonze's then-father-in-law [[Francis Ford Coppola]] was able to contact Malkovich,{{cite news |title=FILM; The Fun and Games of Living a Virtual Life |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/24/arts/film-the-fun-and-games-of-living-a-virtual-life.html |first=Peter |last=Kobel |date=October 24, 1999 |accessdate=November 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128172027/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/24/arts/film-the-fun-and-games-of-living-a-virtual-life.html |archivedate=November 28, 2010 |deadurl=no}} and Jonze flew with producer [[Sandy Stern]] to Malkovich's home in France. Stern said that Malkovich was "half intrigued and half horrified" when he first read the script, but he eventually agreed to star in the film.{{cite news |title=Being Sandy Stern |work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]] |first=Stacie |last=Stukin |page=68 |issue=798 |date=November 9, 1999}} Spike Jonze makes a [[cameo appearance]] as Derek Mantini's assistant; Mantini is billed in the story as the greatest puppeteer in the history of the world and arouses Schwartz's envy. [[Brad Pitt]] also has a half-second-long [[Cameo appearance|cameo]], as a miffed star in the documentary on Malkovich's career, who seems to be on the verge of saying something before the shot ends. [[Sean Penn]] appears as a fictionalized version of himself and a fan of Malkovich's puppeteer work. Film director [[David Fincher]] makes an uncredited appearance as Christopher Bing in the American Arts & Culture [[pseudo-documentary]] on John Malkovich. [[Winona Ryder]], [[Andy Dick]], and the members of [[Hanson (band)|Hanson]] can be seen in the audience of a Malkovich puppet show.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0120601/fullcredits#cast |title=''Being John Malkovich'' (1999) – Full Cast & Crew |work=[[IMDb]] |publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}} == Distribution == === Theatrical release === ''Being John Malkovich'' was given [[limited release]] in the United States theatres on October 22, 1999, and opened across 25 screens. On its opening weekend, the film grossed [[United States dollar|US$]]637,731 across 25 screens with a per-screen average of $25,495.{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117757571.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=B.O. full ''House'' |first=Dade |last=Hayes |date=October 31, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} It expanded to another 150 screens the following week, bringing in $1.9 million with a per-screen average of $10,857.{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117757810.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=Auds ''Bone'' up |first=Dade |last=Hayes |date=November 7, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} In its third week, the film's release widened to 467 locations and grossed $2.4 million, averaging a lower $5,041 per screen with a cumulative gross of $6.1 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117758046.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=''Poke'' pockets monster B.O. |first=Dade |last=Hayes |date=November 14, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} It moved into a [[wide release]] the next week, expanding to 591 screens, and grossed $1.9 million with a 20% drop in ticket sales.{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117758270.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=B.O. shaken, stirred by Bond |first=Dade |last=Hayes |date=November 21, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} Its fifth week brought in $2.2 million with a 17% increase in ticket sales,{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117758382.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=Greatest ''Story'' ever sold |first=Dade |last=Hayes |date=November 28, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} which dropped a further 33% the following week despite further expansion to 624 screens.{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117758642.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=''Toy'' keeps B.O. in toon |first=Dade |last=Hayes |date=December 5, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} It finished its theatrical run after 26 weeks with a total gross of $22,863,596.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=beingjohnmalkovich.htm |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[IMDb]] |title=''Being John Malkovich'' (1999) |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} The film opened in the United Kingdom in March 2000, earning [[Pound sterling|£]]296,282 in its debut week{{cite news |title=Film: Box Office |work=[[The Independent]] |date=March 26, 2000 |author1=Thompson, Jonathan |author2=Redvers, Louise }} and closing after fifteen weeks with a total gross of £1,098,927.{{cite news |title=Film: Box Office |work=[[The Independent]] |date=April 9, 2000 |author1=Thompson, Jonathan |author2=Redvers, Louise }} In France, the film opened in December 1999 with a gross of US$546,000 from 94 venues and went on to further success due to positive reviews and [[word of mouth]].{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117759947.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=Holiday Hit Parade |first=Don |last=Groves |date=December 13, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117760142.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=Oversees auds Bonding |first=Don |last=Groves |date=December 19, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} It grossed $205,100 from 109 screens on its opening weekend in Italy and ticket sales dropped by 37% the following week with a cumulative gross of $480,000 from 82 screens.{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117758661.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |title=''Toy'' joy, Bond blast |first=Mark |last=Woods |date=December 6, 1999 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} Its German release brought in a total of $243,071.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=beingjohnmalkovich.htm |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |title=''Being John Malkovich'' (1999) – Foreign Box Office |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} ''Being John Malkovich'' had a total foreign gross of $9,523,455, combined with its domestic gross to give an international total of over $32 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1999/BEING.php |work=The-Numbers.com |title=''Being John Malkovich'' (1999) |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} === Home media === ''Being John Malkovich'' was initially released in 2000 on [[VHS]], both as a regular edition and a limited edition collector's set,{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Being-John-Malkovich-Orson-Bean/dp/630580706X |work=[[Amazon.com]] |title=''Being John Malkovich'' (VHS) |accessdate=November 7, 2010}}{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Being-John-Malkovich-Limited-Collectors/dp/B00004Z4TT |work=[[Amazon.com]] |title=''Being John Malkovich'' Limited Edition Collector's Set (VHS) (1999) |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} and on [[DVD]], with special features including a theatrical trailer, TV spots, cast and crew biographies, the director's photo album and featurettes on floor 7½ and puppeteering.{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,64702,00.html |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |title=''Being John Malkovich'' |first=David |last=Hochman |date=January 25, 2001 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}} A special edition DVD, released later the same year, included the aforementioned features, an interview with Jonze and two behind-the-scenes featurettes.{{cite web |url=http://www.thedigitalbits.com/reviews/beingjohnmalkovich.html |work=[[The Digital Bits]] |title=''Being John Malkovich'' |first=Bill |last=Hunt |date=May 8, 2000 |accessdate=November 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107151923/http://www.thedigitalbits.com/reviews/beingjohnmalkovich.html |archivedate=November 7, 2011 |df= }} It was released on [[HD DVD]] in 2008. [[The Criterion Collection]] released a special edition of the film on [[Blu-ray]] and DVD in 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.criterion.com/films/28055-being-john-malkovich |title=''Being John Malkovich''; Criterion Collection}} == Soundtrack == {{Infobox album | name = Being John Malkovich: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | artist = Various artists | cover = | alt =
