Oosterhoff | designation1 = Ontario Heritage Act | designation1_offname = | designation1_date = 2003 | designation1_number = Heritage Easement Agreement AT347470 }} }} The '''Royal Ontario Museum''' ('''ROM''', {{lang-fr|Musée royal de l'Ontario}}) is a [[museum]] of [[Art museum|art]], [[Culture|world culture]] and [[natural history]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. It is one of the largest museums in [[North America]] and the largest in Canada. It attracts more than one million visitors every year, making the ROM the most-visited in Canada.{{cite web|title=ROM Announces Record-Breaking 1.35 Million Visitors Annual Attendance|url=https://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/newsroom/press-releases/rom-announces-record-breaking-135-million-visitors-annual|website=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=23 November 2017}} The museum is north of [[Queen's Park (Toronto)|Queen's Park]], in the [[University of Toronto]] district, with its main entrance on [[Bloor Street|Bloor Street West]]. The [[Museum station (Toronto)|Museum subway station]] of the Toronto Transit Commission is named after the ROM and since 2008, it is decorated to resemble the institution's collection. Established on 16 April 1912 and opened on 19 March 1914, the museum has maintained close relations with the University of Toronto throughout its history, often sharing expertise and resources.{{cite book |title=The Museum Makers: the Story of the Royal Ontario Museum |last=Dickson |first=Lovat |year=1986 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=0-8020-7441-3}} The museum was under the direct control and management of the University of Toronto until 1968, when it became an independent [[Crown agency (Ontario)|Crown agency]] of the government of Ontario.{{cite web|last=Jamie|first=Bradburn|title=Historicist: A Handbook to the Royal Ontario Museum, 1956|url=http://torontoist.com/2011/07/historicist_a_handbook_to_the_royal_ontario_museum_1956/|publisher=Torontoist|accessdate=26 March 2012}}{{cite web|title=ROM Trustees|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/rom-leadership/rom-trustees0|website=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=13 January 2016|quote=The Royal Ontario Museum is an agency of the Government of Ontario.}} Today, the museum is Canada's largest field-research institution, with research and conservation activities that span the globe.{{cite web|title=Collections and Research|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/collections/index.php|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=25 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418191455/http://www.rom.on.ca/collections/index.php|archivedate=18 April 2012|df=dmy-all}} With more than 6,000,000 items and 40 galleries, the museum's diverse collections of world culture and natural history contribute to its international reputation. The museum contains notable collections of [[dinosaur]]s, minerals and meteorites, [[Art of Mesopotamia|Near Eastern]] and [[African art]], Art of East Asia, [[History of Europe|European history]] and [[History of Canada|Canadian history]]. It houses the world's largest collection of fossils from the [[Burgess Shale]] with more than 150,000 specimens.{{cite web|title=Royal Ontario Museum Burgess Shale Expeditions (1975-ongoing)|url=http://burgess-shale.rom.on.ca/en/history/discoveries/05-rom.php|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=25 March 2012}} The museum also contains an extensive collection of design and fine arts, including clothing, interior, and product design, especially [[Art Deco]]. ==History== The Royal Ontario Museum was formally established on 16 April 1912{{Cite canlaw|short title =The Royal Ontario Museum Act|abbr =S.O.|year =1912|chapter = 80|link= https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1912onta#page/742/mode/2up}}{{cite web|last=Siddiqui|first=Norman|title=Our History|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/rom/our-history|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=26 September 2013}} and was jointly governed by the [[Government of Ontario]] and the [[University of Toronto]].{{cite web|title=History of the Royal Ontario Museum|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/sites/default/files/imce/newsroom_history.pdf|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=24 March 2012}} Its first assets were transferred from the University and the [[Ministry of Education (Ontario)|provincial Department of Education]], coming from its predecessor the Museum of Natural History and Fine Arts at the [[Toronto Normal School]].For the history of the archaeological and ethnographic collection of the Normal School, later given to the ROM, see Gerald Killan, ''David Boyle: From Artisan to Archaeologist,'' Toronto, University of Toronto Press, 1983 and Michelle A Hamilton, ''Collections and Objections: Aboriginal Material Culture in Southern Ontario'', Montreal: McGill-Queen's University Press, 2010. On 19 March 1914, at 3:00pm, the [[Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn|Duke of Connaught]], also the [[Governor General of Canada]], officially opened the Royal Ontario Museum to the public. The museum's location at the edge of Toronto's built-up area, far from the city's [[central business district]], was selected mainly for its proximity to the University of Toronto. The original building was constructed on the western edge of the property along the university's [[Philosopher's Walk (Toronto)|Philosopher's Walk]], with its main entrance facing out onto [[Bloor Street]] housing five separate museums of the following fields: Archaeology, Palaeontology, Mineralogy, Zoology, and Geology. This was the first phase of a two-part construction plan that intended to expand the museum towards Queen's Park Crescent, ultimately creating an H-shaped structure. [[File:XROMandParkPlaza.jpg|thumb|The Royal Ontario Museum in 1930, three years prior to the opening of its renovation and expansion.]] The first expansion to the Royal Ontario Museum publicly opened on 12 October 1933.{{cite web|title=Our History |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/about/history/index.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329071520/http://www.rom.on.ca/about/history/index.php |archivedate=29 March 2008 |df=dmy }} The renovation saw the construction of the south wing fronting onto Queen's Park and required the demolition of Argyle House, a Victorian mansion at 100 Queen's Park. As this occurred during the [[Great Depression]], an effort was made to use primarily local building materials and to make use of workers capable of manually excavating the building's foundations. Teams of workers alternated weeks of service due to the physically draining nature of the job. In 1947, the ROM was dissolved as a body corporate, with all assets transferred to the University of Toronto.{{Cite canlaw|short title =The Royal Ontario Museum Act, 1947|abbr =S.O.|year =1947|chapter = 96|link= https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1947onta#page/364/mode/2up}} This continued until 1968, when the Museum and the [[McLaughlin Planetarium]] were separated from the University to form a new corporation.{{Cite canlaw|short title =The Royal Ontario Museum Act, 1968|abbr =S.O.|year =1968|chapter = 119|link= https://archive.org/stream/statutesofprovin1968onta#page/520/mode/2up}} On 26 October 1968, the ROM opened the McLaughlin Planetarium on the south end of the property after receiving a $2 million donation from Colonel R. [[Samuel McLaughlin]].{{cite web|title=ROM History |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/newsroom/pdf/rom_history.pdf |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809013541/http://www.rom.on.ca/newsroom/pdf/rom_history.pdf |archivedate=9 August 2011 |df=dmy }} By the 1980s, however, the planetarium's audiences were dwindling and due to budget cuts, the facility was forced to shut down in November 1995. The space temporarily reopened from 1998 to 2002, after being leased to [[Children's Own Museum]]. In 2009, the ROM sold the building to the University of Toronto for $22 million and ensured that it would continue to be used for institutional and academic purposes.{{cite news|last=O'Brien|first=Chrissie|title=Royal Ontario Museum agrees to sell McLaughlin Planetarium site to University of Toronto|url=http://dailycommercialnews.com/article/id32730|accessdate=28 March 2012|newspaper=Daily Commercial News|date=19 February 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220123817/http://dailycommercialnews.com/article/id32730|archivedate=20 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |title=FAQs |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/about/faqs/faqsgen.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418165727/http://www.rom.on.ca/about/faqs/faqsgen.php |archivedate=18 April 2012 |df=dmy }} [[File:McLaughlin Planetarium - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09895.JPG|thumb|left|The [[McLaughlin Planetarium]] next to the museum. The planetarium was operated by the museum from 1968 to 2009.]] The second major addition to the museum was the Queen Elizabeth II Terrace Galleries on the north side of the building and a curatorial centre built on the south, which started in 1978 and was completed in 1984. The new construction meant that a former outdoor "Chinese Garden" to the north of the building facing Bloor, along with an adjoining indoor restaurant, had to be dismantled. Opened in 1984 by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], a $55 million expansion took the form of layered volumes, each rising layer stepping back from Bloor Street-- hence creating a layered terrace effect. The design of this expansion won a [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General's]] [[List of awards presented by the Governor General of Canada|Award in Architecture]].[http://arc.co.uk/149600.arx Royal Ontario Museum Review] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104230145/http://arc.co.uk/149600.arx |date=4 November 2005 }} In 1989, activists complained about its ''Into the Heart of Africa'' exhibit, which featured [[Ethnic stereotype|stereotypes]] of Africans, forcing curator Jeanne Cannizzo to resign.Petersen, Klaus & Allan C. Hutchinson. "Interpreting Censorship in Canada", [[University of Toronto Press]], 1999 Beginning in 2002, the museum underwent a major renovation and expansion project dubbed as ''Renaissance ROM.'' The Provincial and Federal governments, both supporters of this venture, contributed $60 million towards the project.{{cite web |title=Renaissance ROM |url=http://rom.on.ca/support/governors/ren_learn_more.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=24 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721001731/http://www.rom.on.ca/support/governors/ren_learn_more.php |archivedate=21 July 2009 |df=dmy }} The campaign aimed not only to raise annual visitor attendance from 750,000 to between 1.3 and 1.6 million, but also to generate additional funding opportunities to support the museum's research, conservation, galleries and educational public programs.{{cite web|title=Renaissance ROM Fact Sheet |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/about/newsroom/pdf/renromfacts.pdf |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=25 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709201456/http://www.rom.on.ca/about/newsroom/pdf/renromfacts.pdf |archivedate=9 July 2009 |df=dmy }} The centrepiece of the project, the Michael Lee-Chin Crystal, was a major addition to the building's original framework. The structure was created by architect [[Daniel Libeskind]], whose design was selected from among 50 finalists in an international competition.{{cite web|last=Lostracco|first=Marc|title=Inside The ROM Crystal: A First Look|url=http://torontoist.com/2007/05/inside_the_rom/|publisher=Torontoist|accessdate=25 March 2012}} The design saw the Terrace Galleries torn down (the curatorial centre to the south remains) and replaced with a [[Deconstructivism|Deconstructivist]] crystalline-form structure, named after [[Michael Lee-Chin]] who pledged $30 million towards its construction. Existing galleries and buildings were also upgraded, along with the installation of multiple new exhibits over a period of months. The first phase of the Renaissance ROM project, the Ten Renovated Galleries in the Historic Buildings, opened to the public on 26 December 2005. The architectural opening for the Michael Lee-Chin Crystal, however, took place less than 18 months later, on 2 June 2007. The final cost of the project was about $270 million.{{cite web|title=Michael Lee-Chin Crystal Facts |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/about/newsroom/pdf/crystalfacts.pdf |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=25 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709201408/http://www.rom.on.ca/about/newsroom/pdf/crystalfacts.pdf |archivedate=9 July 2009 |df=dmy }} The original building was listed by the City of Toronto on the Municipal Heritage Register on 20 June 1973, designated under Part IV of the ''[[Ontario Heritage Act]]'' in 2003, with a Heritage Easement on the buildings.{{cite web |url= http://app.toronto.ca/HeritagePreservation/details.do?folderRsn=2437577&propertyRsn=224637|title=Heritage Property Detail, Address: 100 QUEEN'S PARK |author= |date= |website=City of Toronto Heritage Property Register |publisher= |access-date=September 22, 2017 |quote=}} ==Buildings and architecture== ===Original building and eastern wing=== [[File:Royal Ontario Museum (outside view, 2005).jpg|thumb|The original building was designed in a [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival style]], punctuated by rounded and segmented arched windows with heavy surrounds and hood mouldings.]] Designed by Toronto architects [[Darling and Pearson|Frank Darling and John A. Pearson]],[http://www.rom.on.ca/about/history/index.php Royal Ontario Museum | About Us | Our History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329071520/http://www.rom.on.ca/about/history/index.php |date=29 March 2008 }} the architectural style of the original building is Italianate [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Neo-Romanesque]], popular throughout North America until the 1870s. The structure is heavily massed and punctuated by rounded and segmented arched windows with heavy surrounds and hood mouldings. Other features include applied decorative eave brackets, [[quoin]]s and [[cornice]]s. The eastern wing facing Queen's Park was designed by [[Chapman and Oxley|Alfred H. Chapman and James Oxley]]. Opened in 1933, it included the museum's elaborate [[Art Deco|art deco]], Byzantine-inspired rotunda and a new main entrance. The linking wing and rear (west) façade of the Queen's Park wing were originally done in the same yellow brick as the 1914 building, with minor Italianate detailing. However, the Queen's Park façade of the expansion broke away from the heavy Italianate style of the original structure. It was built in a [[Byzantine Revival architecture|neo-Byzantine]] style with rusticated stone, triple windows contained within recessed arches and different-coloured stones arranged in a variety of patterns. This development from the Roman-inspired Italianate to a Byzantine-influenced style reflected the historical development of [[Byzantine architecture]] from [[Ancient Roman architecture|Roman architecture]]. Common among neo-Byzantine buildings in North America, the façade also contains elements of [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] in its relief carvings, gargoyles and statues. The ornate ceiling of the rotunda is covered predominantly in gold back-painted glass mosaic tiles, with coloured mosaic geometric patterns and images of real and mythical animals. [[File:DSC09082 - Mosaic Ceiling (36823804840).jpg|thumb|left|The [[mosaic]] ceiling of the [[rotunda (architecture)|rotunda]] is covered predominantly in gold back-painted glass tiles.]] Writing in the Journal of the [[Royal Architectural Institute of Canada]] in 1933, A.S. Mathers said of the expansion: "The interior of the building is a surprise and a pleasant one; the somewhat complicated ornament of the façade is forgotten and a plan on the grand manner unfolds itself. It is simple, direct and big in scale. One is convinced that the early Beaux Arts training of the designer has not been in vain. The outstanding feature of the interior is the glass mosaic ceiling of the entrance rotunda. It is executed in colours and gold and strikes a fine note in the one part of the building which the architect could decorate without conflicting with the exhibits."{{cite web|url=http://speeches.empireclub.org/61643/data?n=1 |title=The Museum: Past, Present and Future, by Dr. James E. Cruise |publisher=Speeches.empireclub.org |date= |accessdate=25 September 2013}} The original building and the 1933 expansion have been listed since 1973 as heritage buildings of Toronto.[http://www.rom.on.ca/renaissance/heritage.php Heritage of the ROM, accessed 10 November 2005] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406011308/http://www.rom.on.ca/renaissance/heritage.php |date=6 April 2004 }} In 2005, a major renovation of the heritage wings saw the galleries made larger, windows uncovered, and the original early 20th-century architecture made more prominent. The exteriors of the heritage buildings were cleaned and restored. The restoration of the 1914 and 1933 buildings was the largest heritage project undertaken in Canada. The renovation also included the newly restored Rotunda with reproductions of the original oak doors, a restored axial view from the Rotunda west through to windows onto Philosophers' Walk and ten renovated galleries comprising a total of {{convert|90000|sqft|m2|sigfig=1}}.ROM Members' News, Winter 2005–6. In the master plan designed by Darling and Pearson in 1909, the ROM took a form similar to that of J.N.L. Durand's ideal model of the museum (published in the early 19th century). It was envisioned as a square plan with corridors running through the centre of the composition, converging in the middle with a domed rotunda. Overall, it referenced the upper-class palaces of the 17th and 18th centuries and aimed at having a strong sense of monumentality. All the architectural elements—the deep cornice, decorative top, eave brackets—add to this strength that the ROM possessed, as it was purely a structure with the function of collecting, but not of exhibiting.Browne, Kelvin. Bold Visions: the Architecture of the Royal Ontario Museum. Toronto: ROM, 2008. During the mid-2010s, the original entrance was used as a café. Since late-2017, the original entrance is undergoing renovation to become an alternate entrance, complete with the addition of ramps to the original entrance. ===Curatorial centre=== Designed by Toronto architect Gene Kinoshita, with Mathers & Haldenby, the curatorial centre forms the southern section of the museum. Completed in 1984, it was built during the same expansion as the former Queen Elizabeth II Terrace Galleries, which stood on north side of the museum. The architecture is a simple [[Modern architecture|modernist]] style of poured concrete, glass, and pre-cast concrete and aggregate panels. The curatorial centre houses the museum's administrative and curatorial services, and provides storage for artifacts that are not on exhibit. In 2006, the curatorial centre was renamed to Louise Hawley Stone Curatorial Centre in honour of the late Louise Hawley Stone, who devoted herself to the ROM throughout her life and she donated a number of artifacts and various collections to the museum. In her will, she transferred C$49.7 million to the Louise Hawley Stone Charitable Trust, created to help with the upkeep of the building and to the acquisition of new artifacts.{{cite web|title=Royal Ontario Museum's News Release|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|url= http://www.rom.on.ca/news/releases/public.php?mediakey=wjo82sxdiw|accessdate=26 March 2012}} ===The Crystal=== [[File:4.Extension of Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto.jpg|thumb|The museum entrance was moved to The Crystal when it opened in 2007.]] The controversial Michael Lee-Chin "Crystal," a multimillion-dollar expansion to the museum including a new sliding door entrance on Bloor Street, first opened in 2007.{{cite web|title=Royal Ontario Museum|url=http://daniel-libeskind.com/projects/royal-ontario-museum|accessdate=28 March 2012}} The [[Deconstructivism|Deconstructivist]] crystalline form is clad in 25 percent [[glass]] and 75 percent [[aluminium]], sitting on top of a [[steel frame]]. ''The Crystal'''s canted walls do not touch the sides of the existing heritage buildings, but are used to close the envelope between the new form and existing walls. These walls act as a pathway for pedestrians to travel safely across "The Crystal." The building's design is similar to some of Libeskind's other works, notably the [[Jewish Museum, Berlin|Jewish Museum]] in [[Berlin]], the [[London Metropolitan University|London Metropolitan University Graduate Centre]] and the [[Denver Art Museum|Fredric C. Hamilton Building]] at the Denver Art Museum.{{cite web|last=Libeskin|first=Daniel|title=Prominent Poles|url=http://www.angelfire.com/scifi2/rsolecki/daniel_libeskind.html}} The steel framework was manufactured and assembled by Walters Inc. of [[Hamilton, Ontario]]. The extruded anodized aluminium cladding was fabricated by Josef Gartner in [[Germany]], the only company in the world that can produce the material. The company also provided the titanium cladding for [[Frank Gehry]]'s [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao|Guggenheim Museum]] in [[Bilbao]], [[Spain]].{{cite web |url=http://www.beijing.gc.ca/beijing/en/1627.htm |title=Canadian Embassy Beijing: New Rom rising |publisher=Beijing.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=25 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202073901/http://www.beijing.gc.ca/beijing/en/1627.htm |archivedate=2 February 2007 |df=dmy }} [[File:Royal Ontario Museum (9674325453).jpg|thumb|left|The overall aim of The Crystal was to provide openness and accessibility, seeking to blur the lines between the public area of the street and the more private area of the museum.]] The overall aim of ''The Crystal'' is to provide openness and accessibility, seeking to blur the lines between the threshold linking the public area of the street and the more private area of the museum. The goal is to act as an open threshold where people and artifacts animate the space. On 1 June 2007, the [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]], [[Michaëlle Jean]], attended the architectural opening of the "Michael Lee-Chin Crystal."http://www.enotes.com/topic/Michaëlle_Jean This caused controversy because public opinion had been divided concerning the merits of its angular design. On its opening, ''[[The Globe and Mail|Globe and Mail]]'' architecture critic Lisa Rochon complained that "the new ROM rages at the world," was oppressive, angsty and hellish, while others-- perhaps championed by her ''[[Toronto Star]]'' counterpart, Christopher Hume-- hailed it as a monument.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/article/220522 |title=''Toronto Star'': Inside the ROM crystal; 1 June 2007 |publisher=Thestar.com |date=1 June 2007 |accessdate=25 September 2013}}{{Not in citation|date=November 2018}} Some critics have gone as far as ranking it as one of the ten ugliest buildings in the world.{{cite news| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/roms-crystal-makes-list-of-worlds-ugliest-buildings/article1370744/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | title=ROM's Crystal makes list of world's ugliest buildings | date=23 August 2012}} The project also experienced budget and construction time over-runs,{{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/article/210627 | title = Crystal vision blurry | author = Readers | work = [[Toronto Star]] | date = 5 May 2007 | accessdate = 14 June 2007 }} and drew comparisons to the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao for using so-called "starchitecture" to attract tourism.{{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/article/210011 | title = It's okay to think it's ugly | author = Joey Slinger | work = [[Toronto Star]] | date = 3 May 2007 | accessdate = 14 June 2007 }} The main lobby is a three-story high atrium, named the Hyacinth Gloria Chen Crystal Court.{{cite web|title=Exhibition Spaces |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/spaces/chen_court.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123082056/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/spaces/chen_court.php |archivedate=23 November 2011 |df=dmy }} The lobby is overlooked by balconies and flanked by the J.P. Driscoll Family Stair of Wonders and the Spirit House, an interstitial space formed by the intersection of the east and west crystals that is intended as a space of emotional and physical diversion.{{cite web|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/about-the-museum/exhibition-spaces/thorsell-spirit-house|title=Thorsell Spirit House - Royal Ontario Museum|website=www.rom.on.ca}} [[File:Royal Ontario Museum inside.JPG|thumb|''Hyacinth Gloria Chen Crystal Court'' is a three-storey high atrium inside The Crystal.]] Installation of the permanent galleries of the Lee-Chin Crystal began mid-June 2007, after a ten-day period when all the empty gallery spaces were open to the public.{{cite web|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/news/releases/public.php?mediakey=7r50pyqwwj |title=News | Royal Ontario Museum |publisher=Rom.on.ca |date= |accessdate=25 September 2013}} Within ''The Crystal,'' there is a gift shop, C5 restaurant lounge (closed until further notice), a cafeteria, seven additional galleries and Canada's largest temporary exhibition hall. The galleries added to the Crystal gave different aspects to the ROM: fascinating visuals, architectural artifacts and environment, art, correspondence between object and space and stories within the visuals.{{cite web|title=Dawn of the Crystal Age |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/crystal/contemplate.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010202246/http://www.rom.on.ca/crystal/contemplate.php |archivedate=10 October 2011 |df=dmy }} The C5 restaurant Lounge is an award-winning designs firm lI BY IV Design Associated Inc.{{cite web|title=Dining|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/dining_shopping/dining/crystal5.php|work=ROM|accessdate=29 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418191329/http://www.rom.on.ca/dining_shopping/dining/crystal5.php|archivedate=18 April 2012|df=dmy-all}} In October 2007, the Lee-Chin Crystal was reported to have suffered from significant water leakage, causing concerns for the building's resilience to weather, especially in the face of the new structure's proximate first winter.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20071003.ROM03/TPStory/TPNational/Ontario/ ''Globe and Mail'': Leaks, woes a smudge on Crystal's sparkle; 3 October 2007] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319031948/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20071003.ROM03/TPStory/TPNational/Ontario/ |date=19 March 2009 }} Although a two-layer cladding system was incorporated into the design of the Crystal to prevent the formation of dangerous snow loads on the structure, past architectural creations of Daniel Libeskind (including the [[Denver Art Museum]]) have suffered from weather-related complications.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070518.wrom0519/BNStory/Entertainment ''Globe and Mail'': A Crystal with its fair share of wrinkles; 18 May 2007] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318071118/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20070518.wrom0519/BNStory/Entertainment |date=18 March 2009 }}{{cite web|url=http://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/070411denverartmuseum.asp |title=''Architectural Record'': Repairs at Denver Art Museum Set to Begin; 11 April 2007 |publisher=Archrecord.construction.com |date= |accessdate=25 September 2013}} ==Galleries== Originally, there were five major galleries at the ROM, one each for the fields of [[archaeology]], [[geology]], [[mineralogy]], [[paleontology]] and [[zoology]].{{cite web|url=http://archaeology.about.com/library/products/blprrom.htm |title=Guide Rating and Review: Large Museum Shops, accessed 10 November 2005 |publisher=Archaeology.about.com |date=12 July 2013 |accessdate=25 September 2013}} In general, the museum pieces were labelled and arranged in a static fashion that had changed little since Edwardian times. For example, the insects' exhibit that lasted up until the 1970s housed a variety of specimens from different parts of the world in long rows of glass cases. Insects of the same genus were pinned to the inside of the cabinet, with only the species name and location found as a description. [[File:Lobby - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09843.JPG|thumb|Used as the museum's lobby, the ''Samuel Hall Currelly Gallery'' showcases an assortment of items from the museum's collection.]] By the 1960s, more interpretive displays were ushered in, among the first being the original dinosaur gallery, established in the mid-1960s. Dinosaur fossils were now staged in dynamic poses against backdrop paintings and models of contemporaneous landscapes and vegetation. The displays became more descriptive and interpretive sometimes, as with the extinction of the woolly mammoth, offering several different leading theories on the issue for the visitor to ponder. This trend continued and up until the present time, the galleries became less staid and more dynamic or descriptive and interpretive. This trend arguably came to a culmination in the 1980s with the opening of The Bat Cave, where a sound system, strobe lights and gentle puffs of air attempts to recreate the experience of walking through a cave as a colony of bats fly out. The original galleries were simply named after their subject material, but in more recent years, individual galleries have been named in honour of sponsors who have donated significant funds or collections to the institution. There are now two main categories of galleries present in the ROM: the Natural History Galleries and the World Culture Galleries. The ''Samuel Hall Currelly Gallery'' is an exhibition space on Level 1, connecting the east wing of the museum with its western half. The gallery serves as the building's main lobby past the museum's admission area. As opposed to the most galleries at the Royal Ontario Museum, the ''Samuel Hall Currelly Gallery'' is not dedicated to a single subject. Instead, the gallery exhibits an assortment of items from the museum's collection.{{cite web|url=https://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/rom/exhibition-spaces/samuel-hall-currelly-gallery|title=Samuel Hall Currelly Gallery|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=19 August 2018}} ===Costumes and textiles=== [[File:General view - Patricia Harris Gallery of Textiles & Costume, Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09417.JPG|thumb|The ''Patricia Harris Gallery of Costumes and Textiles'' holds around 200 artifacts from the museum's textile and costume collection.]] The ''Patricia Harris Gallery of Costumes and Textiles'' holds about 200 artifacts from the ROM's textile and costume collections. These pieces, which range from the 1st century BC to the present day, are rotated frequently due to their fragility. Throughout time, textiles and fashion have been used to establish identity and allow inferences to be drawn about a culture's social customs, economy and survival. The gallery is devoted to showcasing transformations in textile design, manufacturing, and cultural relevance throughout the ages. Weaving, needlework, printed archaeological textiles and silks are all located in this space.{{cite web|title=Patricia Harris Gallery of Textiles & Costume|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/patricia-harris-gallery-textiles-costume|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=19 September 2013}} ===Interactive galleries=== The ''CIBC Discovery Gallery'' was designed to be a kids' learning zone. It houses three main areas: In the Earth, Around the World and Close to Home. The space is inspired by the ROM's collections and enables children to participate in interactive activities involving touchable artifacts and specimens, costumes, digging for dinosaur bones and examining fossils and meteorites. There is also a special area for pre-schoolers.{{cite web|title=CIBC Discovery Gallery|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/hands-galleries/cibc-discovery-gallery|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=19 September 2013}} The ''Patrick and Barbara Keenan Family Gallery of Hands-On Biodiversity'' introduces visitors to the complicated relationships which occur among all living things in a fun and interactive space. People of all ages can explore touchable specimens and interactive displays while gallery facilitators help visitors discover the living world around them. Mossy frogs, a touchable shark jaw, snake skin and a replica fox's den are just some of the objects that connect visitors to the amazing diversity and interdependence of plants and animals.{{cite web|title=Patrick and Barbara Keenan Family Gallery of Hands-on Biodiversity|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/hands-galleries/patrick-and-barbara-keenan-family-gallery-hands|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=19 September 2013}} ===Institute for Contemporary Culture gallery=== The Roloff Beny Gallery of the [[Institute for Contemporary Culture]] (ICC) hosts the Royal Ontario Museum's contemporary art exhibitions.{{cite web|url=http://torontoartsonline.org/content/view/full/10566/ |title=Toronto Arts Online |publisher=Toronto Arts Online |date=7 September 2009 |accessdate=25 September 2013}} This high-ceilinged multimedia gallery of approximately {{convert|6000|sqft|m2|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} serves as the ICC's main exhibition space and the ROM's window on contemporary society, striving to connect the ROM's vast natural history and world cultures collection to contemporary art and events.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/article821493.ece Interview of William Thorsell, Director of the Royal Ontario Museum. The Globe and Mail.] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The gallery has featured exhibitions on fashion photography,{{cite web|author=Ignacio Villarreal|url=http://www.artdaily.com/section/news/index.asp?int_sec=2&int_new=33570&b=institute%20for%20contemporary%20culture|title=Artdaily.org – The First Art Newspaper|publisher=Artdaily.com|date=|accessdate=25 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001204441/http://artdaily.com/section/news/index.asp?int_sec=2&int_new=33570&b=institute%20for%20contemporary%20culture|archivedate=1 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} street art,{{cite web|url=http://housepaint.typepad.com/housepaint/about-housepaint-phase-2-.html |title=Housepaint Blog |publisher=Housepaint.typepad.com |date=13 December 2008 |accessdate=25 September 2013}} modern Chinese urban design and architecture,{{cite web|url=http://www.blogto.com/arts/2008/05/the_roms_shanghai_kaleidoscope/ |title=BlogTO |publisher=BlogTO |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=25 September 2013}} and contemporary Japanese art.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/article793233.ece Hiroshi Sugimoto in The Globe and Mail] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ===Natural History galleries=== [[File:Biodiversity exhibit - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC00209.JPG|thumb|The second floor of the museum contains collections and samples of various animals.]] The Natural History galleries are all gathered on the second floor of the museum. The gallery contains collections and samples of various animals such as bats, birds, and dinosaur bones and skeletons. ''The Life in Crisis: Schad Gallery of Biodiversity,'' designed by Reich+Petch and opened in late-2009, features [[Endangered species|endangered]] species, including specimens of a [[polar bear]], a [[giant panda]], a [[white rhinoceros]], a [[Burmese python]], [[Deep-water coral|Canadian coral]], a [[leatherback sea turtle]], a [[coelacanth]], a [[Rafflesia]] flower and many other rare species. Included among these specimens is [[Southern White Rhino ("Bull")|Bull]], a [[southern white rhinoceros]] that became a famous conservation success story for his species.{{cite web|url=https://www.rom.on.ca/en/node/2840|title=Images|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} There are also [[Holocene extinction|recently extinct]] species displayed, including specimens of a [[passenger pigeon]] and a [[great auk]], as well as skeletons of a [[dodo]] and a [[moa]] with a specimen of a moa egg and many other recently extinct species. The gallery presents the need to protect the natural environment and the need to educate the public about the main causes of [[extinction]]—overhunting, habitat destruction, and climate change. In September 2009, the gallery received an Award of Excellence by the Association of Registered Interior Designers of Ontario. The Schad Gallery of Biodiversity is not merely an exhibition gallery showcasing Earth's wondrous specimens, but a lesson for the future care of the planet. The ''Life in Crisis'' gallery is organized into three zones exploring the central themes: Life is Diverse, Life is interconnected, and Life is at Risk. "Interestingly, biodiversity is a relatively new term popularized in 1985 as a contraction of biological diversity" said Anthony Reich, Principal at Reich+Petch. "It's a big subject that's become more relevant to everybody. The challenge was how to tell this big story in a {{convert|10,000|sqft|m2|adj=on|sigfig=1}} space. We decided to design a dynamic, immersive experience with three core themes that hopefully will make a lasting impression on visitors."{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianinteriors.com/news/reich--biodiversity--petch/1000342195/ |title=Reich + biodiversity + Petch|work= canadianinteriors.com|date= 1 September 2009|accessdate= 1 February 2013}} The ''Tallgrass Prairies and Savannas'' is a part of the gallery that features one of the most endangered and diverse habitats in Ontario. The display features examples of the regions and the efforts by the Ontario [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry]], to maintain and restore the tall grass prairies and savannas. [[File:Bird exhibit - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC00188.JPG|thumb|left|The museum has a large collections of birds from past centuries for viewing.]] The ''Gallery of Birds'' has on display many bird specimens from past centuries. The Gallery of Birds is dominated by the broad "Birds in flight" display where stuffed birds are enclosed in a glass display for visitors to experience. Dioramas allow visitors to learn about the many bird species and how environmental and habitual changes have put bird species in danger of extinction. Pull-out drawers let visitors examine eggs, feathers, footprints and nests more closely.{{cite web|title=Gallery of Birds |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/nhistory/nhbirds.php |accessdate=26 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121103951/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/nhistory/nhbirds.php |archivedate=21 January 2012 |df=dmy }} The gallery included exhibits of other extinct species such as the passenger pigeon. These exhibits were later moved to the Schad Gallery. The Royal Ontario Museum purchased a beached [[blue whale]] off the coast of [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] at [[Trout River, Newfoundland and Labrador|Trout River]] and displayed its skeleton and heart.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/blue-whale-bones-one-step-closer-to-display-1.3645458|title=Digging up bones: Royal Ontario Museum moves to next stage of blue whale project|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/blue-whale-mark-engstrom-trout-river-rocky-harbour-rom-1.3655894|title=Researchers hope to learn secrets in blue whale bones|publisher=}} It was displayed as a ROM original travelling exhibit until 4 September 2017. The [[Royal Ontario Museum Bat Cave|Bat Cave]] is an immersive experience for visitors that presents over 20 bats and 800 models in a recreated habitat, with accompanying educational panels and video.{{cite web|title=The Bat Cave|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/natural-history/bat-cave|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=23 September 2013}} Originally opened in 1988, the bat cave reopened on 27 February 2010 after extensive renovations.{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/life/parent/2010/02/24/the_rom_reopens_the_bat_cave.html |title=The ROM reopens the bat cave, accessed 15 October 2013 |publisher=thestar.com |date=4 February 2010 |accessdate=15 October 2013}} The {{convert|1700|sqft|m2|adj=on}} exhibit most notably includes a recreation of [[Saint Catherine Parish#Tourist Sites|St. Clair Cave]] located in central Jamaica. The original cave was formed by an underground river that flowed {{convert|30|m}} below ground through the limestone and was three kilometres long. This cave was then recreated in the museum based on ROM fieldwork conducted in Jamaica in 1984.{{cite web|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/newsroom/press-releases/the-bat-cave-is-back |title=The Bat Cave is back, accessed 15 October 2013 |publisher=rom.on.ca |date=25 February 2010 |accessdate=15 October 2013}} A large amount of bat research has been conducted with support from the ROM. In 2011, the ROM hosted a "bat workshop" connected with the 41st Annual North American Symposium on Bat Research.{{cite web|url=http://www.batcon.org/pdfs/education/Bat%20Workshop%20Toronto.PDF |title=Bat Workshop:41st Annual North American Symposium on Bat Research, accessed 15 October 2013 |publisher=batcon.org |accessdate=15 October 2013}} ====Earth and space==== [[File:Cerussite, Royal Ontario Museum.jpg|thumb|The world's largest faceted [[cerussite]], the [[Light of the Desert]], on display at the ''Teck Suite of Galleries''.]] The ''Teck Suite of Galleries: Earth's Treasures'' features almost 3,000 specimens of minerals, gems, meteorites and rocks ranging from 4.5 billion years ago to the present. These items were found in many different locations including the Earth, Moon and beyond, and represent the world's dynamic geological environment.{{cite web|title=Tech Suite of Galleries: Earth's Treasures|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/natural-history/teck-suite-galleries-earths-treasures|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=9 September 2013}} Notable specimens at the ''Teck Suite of Galleries'' include fragments of the [[Tagish Lake (meteorite)|Tagish Lake meteorite]].{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/5721/tagish-lake?ctx=6f84e716-7b4e-42b1-8be0-fe15db25b9f8&idx=1|title=Tagish Lake|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=20 August 2018|year=2018}} The [[Light of the Desert]], the world's largest faceted [[cerussite]], is another notable piece displayed in the gallery.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/5240/cerussite-light-of-the-desert?ctx=a6ccaf84-bec8-4824-b839-ce8f8f7d4c37&idx=0|title=Cerussite, Light of the Desert|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=20 August 2018|year=2018}} Galleries that are a part of the ''Teck Suite of Galleries'' include the ''Barrick Gold Corporation Gallery,'' the ''Canadian Mining Hall of Fame Gallery,'' the ''Gallery of Gems and Gold'' and the ''Vale Gallery of Minerals.'' ====Fossils and evolution==== [[File:ChasmosaurusROM.JPG|thumb|The ROM has a collection of fossils from the [[Jurassic]] to [[Cenozoic]] periods.]] The ''Reed Gallery of the Age of Mammals'' explores the rise of mammals through the [[Cenozoic]] Era that followed the extinction of the dinosaurs. There are over 400 specimens from North America and South America on display. Also included in the gallery are 30 fossil skeletons of extinct mammals, over 160 non-mammalian specimens and hundreds of fossil plants, insects, fish and turtles. The gallery's entrance begins with mammals that arose shortly after the [[extinction]] of the non-avian dinosaurs. A highlight of this gallery is the sabre-toothed [[Nimravidae|nimravid]] [[Dinictis]]. The ''James and Louise Temerty Galleries of the Age of Dinosaurs'' and ''Gallery of the Age of Mammals'' feature many examples of complete [[dinosaur]] skeletons, as well as those of early birds, reptiles, mammals and marine animals ranging from the [[Jurassic]] to [[Cretaceous]] periods. The highlight of the exhibit is [[Gordo (dinosaur)|Gordo]], one of the most complete examples of the ''[[Barosaurus]]'' in North America and the largest dinosaur on display in Canada.Greenwood Davis, Heather. [https://archive.is/20130418193721/http://mediacentre.canada.travel/content/travel_story_ideas/dinosaur-found "Dinosaur found"], ''[[Canadian Tourism Commission]]'', Retrieved on 31 January 2013. ===World Culture galleries=== The World Culture galleries display a wide variety of objects from around the world. These range from [[Stone Age]] implements from [[China]] and [[Africa]] to [[20th-century art]] and design.{{cite web|title=World Cultures|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=26 March 2012}} In July 2011, the museum added to this collection when a number of new permanent galleries were unveiled. Both the Government of Canada and the Royal Ontario Museum committed $2.75 million toward the project.{{cite web|title=Federal Investment Creates New Permanent Galleries at the Royal Ontario Museum |url=http://news.gc.ca/web/article-eng.do?nid=608839 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713085650/http://news.gc.ca/web/article-eng.do?nid=608839 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 July 2012 |publisher=Government of Canada |accessdate=26 March 2012 }} The galleries are located on the first, third and fourth levels of the museum. ====Africa, the Americas, Asia-Pacific, and South Asian==== [[File:Ajmera Gallery interior - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09556.JPG|thumb|Exhibits at the ''Shreyas and Mina Ajmera Gallery of Africa, the Americas and Asia-Pacific'', one of several world culture galleries at the museum.]] The ''Shreyas and Mina Ajmera Gallery of Africa, the Americas and Asia-Pacific'' features a collection of 1,400 artifacts that reflect the artistic and cultural traditions of the indigenous peoples from four different geographical areas: Africa, the American continents, the [[Asia-Pacific]] region and [[Oceania]]. On display are objects such as ceremonial masks, ceramics and even a [[shrunken head]].{{cite web |title=Shreyas and Mina Ajmera Gallery of Africa, the Americas and Asia-Pacific |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/americas.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219010551/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/americas.php |archivedate=19 December 2011 |df=dmy }} The ''Sir Christopher Ondaatje South Asian Gallery'' holds a diverse collection of objects such as decorative art, armour and sculptures that represents the culture of [[South Asia]]. The gallery has approximately 350 objects that represent over 5,000 years of history. Due to the wide range of history and cultures on display, the gallery is split into numerous different sections-- the ''Material Remains,'' ''Imagining the Buddha,'' ''Visualizing Divinity,'' ''Passage to Enlightenment,'' ''Courtly Culture,'' ''Cultural Exchange'' and ''Home and the World.''{{cite web |title=Sir Christopher Ondaatje South Asian Gallery |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/southasia.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120825224825/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/southasia.php |archivedate=25 August 2012 |df=dmy }} In this gallery, visitors can find one of the ROM's Iconic Objects, the [[(Untitled) Blue Lady|(''Untitled'') Blue Lady]] by Navjot Altaf, listed as one of the museum's "must see" objects.[http://www.rom.on.ca/en/collections-research/rom-channel/iconic-blue-lady "Iconic: Blue Lady (Video)"], ''Royal Ontario Museum''. Retrieved on 18 February 2013. ====Ancient==== The ''Eaton Gallery of Rome'' is home to a millennium of ancient Roman culture. It has the largest collection of classical antiquities in Canada, displaying more than 500 objects that range from marble or painted portraits of historical figures to magnificent Roman jewellery. The gallery also features the Bratty Exhibit of Etruria that sheds some light on the [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscans]], a neighbouring civilization.{{cite web|title=Eaton Gallery of Rome|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/eaton-gallery-rome|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} [[File:Antiquities collection - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09783.JPG|thumb|left|The Royal Ontario Museum home to an extensive collection of Roman artifacts.]] The ''Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of Rome and the Near East'' depicts the lifestyle and culture of societies under Roman rule and their influence in the Near East.{{cite web|title=Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of Rome and the Near East |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/rome_neareast.phpp |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The ''Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of Byzantium'' covers the history of the Byzantine Empire from 330 to 1453 AD, during which crucial changes took place in early eastern Christianity. There are over 230 artifacts that relate to the dedication of Constantinople, the fall of the Roman Empire, the Medieval Crusades and the conquest by the Ottoman Turks — items such as jewelry, glass work and coins help to illustrate the vast history of modern-day Istanbul.{{cite web |title=Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of Byzantium |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/byzantium.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421192804/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/byzantium.php |archivedate=21 April 2012 |df=dmy }} The ''A.G. Leventis Foundation Gallery of Ancient [[Cyprus]]'' houses roughly 300 artifacts, focusing on the art created in Cyprus between 2200–30 BC. The gallery is divided into five sections: ''Cyprus and Commerce,'' ''Ancient Cypriot Pottery Types,'' ''Sculptures,'' ''Ancient Cyprus at a Glance'' and ''Art & Society: Interpretations.'' The collection includes a reconstructed open-air sanctuary and a rare bronze relief statue of a man carrying a large copper ingot.{{cite web |title=The A.G. Leventis Foundation Gallery of Ancient Cyprus |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/cyprus.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225072539/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/cyprus.php |archivedate=25 December 2011 |df=dmy }} [[File:Egyptian collection - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09738.JPG|thumb|The ''Gallery of Africa: Egypt'' includes a number of [[cartonnage]]s.]] The ''Gallery of Africa: Egypt'' focuses on the life (and the [[afterlife]]) of [[Ancient Egypt]]ians. It includes a wide range of artifacts, ranging from agricultural implements, jewelry, cosmetics, funerary furnishings and more. The exhibit includes a number of mummy cases, including the fine gilded and painted coffin and mummy of [[Djedmaatesankh]], who was a female musician at the temple of [[Amun|Amun-Re]] in [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]]; and the mummy of Antjau, who is thought to have been a wealthy landowner.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/195676/coffin-and-mummy-of-the-lady-djedmaatesankh?ctx=d01b81df-2696-4fcb-8684-448e9dcf5e92&idx=0|title=Coffin and mummy of the lady Djedmaatesankh|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} Other items featured in the gallery include the ''[[Book of the Dead of Amen-em-hat]],'' a seven-metre long scroll from c. 320 BC and the ''[[Bust of Cleopatra]]'' from c. 47–30 BC.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/202750/book-of-the-dead-fragment-anubis?ctx=f87a0997-bfba-40e4-a748-acca2dd99f15&idx=0|title=Book of the Dead fragment, Anubis|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|date=20 August 2018}} {{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/181138/sculpture-probably-of-cleopatra-vii?ctx=301753d3-79d2-4d9a-95c7-3fe3a34861e5&idx=9|title=Sculpture, probably of Cleopatra VII|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|date=20 August 2018}} The [[Statue of Sekhmet]] can also be viewed at the gallery. Depicting [[Sekhmet]], one of ancient Egypt's oldest deities, the item dates back to c. 1390–1325 BC.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/203913/statue-of-lionheaded-goddess-sekhmet?ctx=d17278fa-b385-4b34-ba63-7bae3b1cf221&idx=0|title=Statue of lion-headed goddess Sekhmet|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|date=20 August 2018}} The ''Galleries of Africa: Nubia'' feature a collection of objects that explore the once flourishing civilization of [[Nubia]] in modern-day Sudan. The Nubians were the first urban literary society in Africa south of the Sahara and were Egypt's main rival.{{cite web|title=Galleries of Africa: Nubia |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/nubia.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211063512/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/nubia.php |archivedate=11 December 2011 |df=dmy }} The ''Gallery of the Bronze Age Aegean'' features over 100 objects that include examples from the [[Cyclades|Cycladic]], [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]], [[Mycenaean Greece|Mycenaean]] and Geometric periods of Ancient Greece. The collection ranges in age from 3200–700 BC and contains a variety of objects that include a marble head of a female figure and a glass necklace.{{cite web|title=Gallery of the Bronze Age Aegean |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/bronze.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123081938/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/bronze.php |archivedate=23 November 2011 |df=dmy }} The ''Gallery of Greece'' has a collection of 1,500 artifacts that span the [[Archaic Greece|Archaic]], [[Classical Greece|Classical]] and [[Hellenistic Greece|Hellenistic]] periods. This time span witnessed the bit of Western art. The collection consists of items such as sculptures of deities, armour and a coin collection.{{cite web |title=Gallery of Greece |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/greece.php |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=28 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111211064217/http://www.rom.on.ca/exhibitions/wculture/greece.php |archivedate=11 December 2011 |df=dmy }} ====Canadiana==== [[File:Canoes - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC00284.JPG|thumb|Canoes used by the [[First Nations]] at ''The Daphne Cockwell Gallery of Canada: First Peoples''.]] ''The Daphne Cockwell Gallery of Canada: First Peoples'' provides a look inside the culture of Canada's earliest societies: the [[Aboriginal people of Canada|Aboriginal Peoples of Canada]]. The gallery contains more than 1,000 artifacts that help to reveal the economic and social forces that have influenced Native art. The Royal Ontario Museum holds a major but little-known collection of Northwest coast native art and artifacts acquired by the Reverend Dr. Richard Whitfield Large at [[Bella Bella, British Columbia]] between 1899 and 1906 known as the ''R.W. Large Collection.'' Although the collection is one of the most important [[Heiltsuk]] collections in existence because of its unique documentation, there has never been a comprehensive study of it.Black, Martha Bella Bella: A Season of Heiltsuk Art. Royal Ontario Museum. 1997. p.2 {{ISBN|1-55054-556-6}} Subject of the book Bella Bella: A Season of Heiltsuk Art, the collection was also part of the Kaxlaya Gvilas (Heiltsuk) exhibit put together collaboratively with the Heiltsuk Nation and the [[University of British Columbia]]. There is also a rotating display of contemporary Native art, an area dedicated to the works of pioneer artist [[Paul Kane]] and a theatre devoted to traditional storytelling.{{cite web|title=Daphne Cockwell Gallery of Canada: First Peoples|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/daphne-cockwell-gallery-canada-first-peoples|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} Just outside this gallery, the central staircase winds around the [[Nisga'a and Haida Crest Poles of the Royal Ontario Museum]], one of the museum's iconic objects.[http://www.rom.on.ca/en/collections-research/rom-channel/iconic-totem-poles "Iconic: Totem Poles (Video)"], ''Royal Ontario Museum'', 29 August 2012. Retrieved on 2 March 2013. The ''Sigmund Samuel Gallery of Canada'' is located on the Weston Family Wing, displaying collections of early Canadian memorabilia, the majority of which is historical decorative and pictorial arts, but also includes a number of historical artifacts among other things. The gallery has approximately 560 artifacts on display and covers the period from early European settlement to the beginning of the modern industrial era. The displays are split up into sections to display the strength and weaknesses of the collections and strongly reflect the French and British cultural heritage of [[Canada]].{{cite web|title=Sigmund Samuel Gallery of Canada|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/sigmund-samuel-gallery-canada|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} A notable item from the museum's collection that are featured at the ''Sigmund Samuel Gallery of Canada'' include ''[[The Death of General Wolfe]]'' by [[Benjamin West]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rom.on.ca/en/node/6513|title=Sigmund Samuel Gallery of Canada|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} ====East Asian==== The Chinese Galleries comprise four sections: the ''[[Bishop White Gallery of Chinese Temple Art]],'' the ''Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of China,'' the ''Matthews Family Court of Chinese Sculpture'' and the ''ROM Gallery of Chinese Architecture.'' [[File:Bishop White Gallery, Royal Ontario Museum.jpg|thumb|left|The ''[[Bishop White Gallery of Chinese Temple Art]]'' include three of the world's best-preserved temple wall paintings from the [[Yuan dynasty]].]] The ''Bishop White Gallery of Chinese Temple Art'' gallery contains three of the world's best-preserved temple wall paintings from the [[Yuan dynasty]] (AD 1271–1386) and a number of wooden sculptures depicting various [[bodhisattva]]s from the 12th to 15th centuries.{{cite web|title=Bishop White Gallery of Chinese Temple Art|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/bishop-white-gallery-chinese-temple-art|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} Chinese temple wall paintings featured in this gallery include the ''[[Homage to the Highest Power]],'' a [[Taoism|Daoist]] wall painting dating to c. 1300 and ''[[Paradise of Maitreya]],'' another Chinese wall temple painting from 1298.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/335520/the-paradise-of-maitreya-wallpainting?ctx=5845c3fd-02e8-4af3-bd44-f1da3ebf4c44&idx=0|title=The Paradise of Maitreya wall-painting|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/338815/daoist-wall-painting-homage-to-the-highest-power-west-wal?ctx=fc171382-cafe-4c51-99f6-ef781d0c9ca6&idx=0|title=Daoist wall painting "Homage to the Highest Power" (west wall)|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} The ''Matthews Family Court of Chinese Sculpture'' has a wide variety of sculptures that span 2,000 years of Chinese sculptural art. It also displays a number of smaller objects that explore the development of religions in China from the 3rd to 19th centuries AD.{{cite web|title=Matthews Family Court of Chinese Sculpture|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/matthews-family-court-chinese-sculpture|year=2018|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} The gallery features several notable items from the museum's collection, including [[Wei Bin's Temple Bell]], a ceremonial bell crafted in 1518 and the [[Companion statues: Kashyapa and Ananda|companion statues of Kashyapa and Ananda]], two statues that originate from the [[Tang dynasty]].{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/338697/temple-bell-of-wei-bin?ctx=509a6a8c-fcdd-47f5-a54e-19e0aba8668c&idx=0|title=Temple bell of Wei Bin|year=2018|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=20 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/350172/figure-of-the-monk-ananda?ctx=a7722caa-a887-4b86-90e6-c21647ff16d9&idx=1|title=Figure of the monk Ananda|year=2018|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} The gallery also features one of the [[Yixian glazed pottery luohans]], a glazed sculpture that dates to the 11th century AD.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/348239/figure-of-a-luohan?ctx=54db9225-c3af-46a1-8fd5-9624d476b107&idx=0|title=Figure of a luohan|year=2018|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} The ''Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of China'' consists of approximately 2,500 objects spanning almost 7,000 years of Chinese history. The gallery is divided into five sections: the ''T. T. Tsui Exhibit of Prehistory and Bronze Age''; the ''Qin and Han Dynasties''; the ''Michael C.K. Lo Exhibition of North, South, Sui and Tang''; ''the Song, Yuan and Frontier Dynasties''; and the ''Ming and Qing Dynasties.'' Each section focuses on a different period of Chinese history, displaying objects ranging from jade discs to pieces of furniture.{{cite web|title=Joey and Toby Tanenbaum Gallery of China|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/joey-and-toby-tanenbaum-gallery-china|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} The ''ROM Gallery of Chinese Architecture'' houses one of the largest collection of [[Chinese architecture|Chinese architectural]] artifacts outside of China and is the first gallery of Chinese architecture in North America. Artifacts held in the gallery include the [[Tomb of General Zu Dashou]]. The tomb includes an assortment of related artifacts, including the altar, stone burial mound and archway.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/324170/tomb-mound-of-general-zu-dashou?ctx=866221e5-1eec-4277-abdf-36dfc5651da7&idx=0|title=Tomb mound of General Zu Dashou|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} The gallery holds some spectacular exhibits such as a [[Imperial Palace Hall Reconstruction|reconstruction of an Imperial Palace building]] from [[Beijing]]'s [[Forbidden City]] and a [[Ming dynasty|Ming]]-era tomb complex.{{cite web|title=ROM Gallery of Chinese Architecture|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/rom-gallery-chinese-architecture|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} [[File:Buddhist reliquary sarira casket, Korea, Unified Silla period, 8th-9th century, copper and gilt bronze - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC04195.JPG|thumb|upright|A Buddhist reliquary sarira casket at the ''Gallery of Korea'', the only gallery of [[Korean art]] in Canada.]] The ''Gallery of Korea'' is the only gallery of [[Korean art]] in Canada. With approximately 260 objects and artifacts, the gallery brings to life Korean and culture. Furniture, ceramics, metalwork, printing technology, painting and decorative arts, dating from the 3rd to 20th centuries AD, illustrate the many accomplishments to Korean culture. [[Buddhism]] being a large part of the Korean culture was introduced to them through China and took hold on the general population. The influence of Buddhism on the Korean culture is portrayed with two statues, the first being a [[Śarīra|Sarira]] casket which originated in India and were made to enshrine the remains of a [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] or enlightened masters{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Matthew|title=The Sarira Casket|url=http://londonkoreanlinks.net/2008/09/27/the-sarira-casket/|accessdate=27 March 2012}} and the second of a tomb guardian. The ''Prince Takamado Gallery of Japan'' contains the largest collection of [[Japanese art]]works in Canada, featuring a rotating display of [[ukiyo-e]] prints and the only tea master collection in North America. Notable pieces of Japanese art featured in the ''Prince Takamado Gallery of Japan'' include ''[[Fan print with two bugaku dancers]]'' and ''[[Unit 88-9 (Kiyomizu Masahiro)|Unit 88-9]].''{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/346563/fan-print-with-two-bugaku-dancers-in-landscape?ctx=4c26d116-fab0-45d0-9678-c57a6d6cf15e&idx=0|title=Fan print with two Bugaku Dancers in landscape|year=2018|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=20 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/307226/unit-889?ctx=78a615a7-5ba3-469c-adf8-e69fcc1ce0de&idx=0|title="Unit 88-9"|year=2018|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=20 August 2018}} The gallery is split into a number of different sections, each home to the collection of objects that the name suggests: the ''Toyota Canada Inc. Exhibit of Ukiyo-e Pictures,'' the ''Sony Exhibit of Painting,'' the ''Canon Canada Inc. Samurai Exhibit,'' the ''Mitsui and Co. Canada Tea Ceremony Exhibit,'' the ''Maple Leaf Foods Exhibit of Lacquers'' and the ''Linamar Corporation Exhibit of Ceramics.'' The gallery is named in honour of the late Japanese [[Norihito, Prince Takamado|Prince Takamado]] (also known as Norihito), who spent several years at [[Queen's University]] in [[Kingston, Ontario]].{{cite web|title=Prince Takamado Gallery of Japan|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/prince-takamado-gallery-japan|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=22 August 2013}} The ''Herman Herzog Levy Gallery'' is the primary venue for East Asian exhibitions visiting the museum.{{cite web|url=https://www.rom.on.ca/en/about-us/rom/exhibition-spaces/herman-herzog-levy-gallery|title=Herman Herzog Levy Gallery|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|date=19 August 2018}} The [[Portrait of Namjar]] was previously displayed in the gallery, although it was later removed and taken to storage.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/295392/hanging-scroll-portrait-of-secondrank-bodyguard-namjar?ctx=c48f4037-0cac-40a5-91e1-e9490f38dbf6&idx=0|title=Hanging scroll portrait of second-rank bodyguard Namjar|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} ====European==== The ''Samuel European Galleries'' have over 4,600 objects that chronicle the development of decorative and other arts in Europe from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. The period rooms depict the development of decorative arts in Central and Western Europe by showcasing changes in style during the Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo, Neoclassical and Victorian periods. Other specialized collections relating to Culture and Context, Judaica, Art Deco and Arms and Armour are also displayed.{{cite web|title=Samuel European Galleries|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/samuel-european-galleries|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=10 September 2013}} An iconic piece at the ''Samuel European Galleries'' is the [[Earl of Pembroke's Armour]]. Dating from 1550 to 1570, the armour was crafted for [[William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke (died 1570)|William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke]].{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/548981/anime-cuirass-small-garniture-for-battle?ctx=0487136a-e490-459e-a2e6-1b4fb095f865&idx=1|title=Anime Cuirass, Small Garniture for Battle|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} Another notable pieces from the museum's European collection is the [[Otho]] [[Tazza (cup)|tazza]].{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/294055/the-aldobrandini-tazza-with-a-figure-of-the-roman-emperor?ctx=8efe994d-3928-4e14-abb6-938ba3be33b6&idx=0|title="The Aldobrandini Tazza" with a figure of the Roman Emperor Otho (Marcus Silvius Otho (32-69; reigned Jan 15, 69 - Apr. 16, 69)|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} The piece was one of 12 tazzas that made up the [[Aldobrandini Tazze]], a set of Renaissance era cups that featured the first 12 Roman emperors whose lives are described in ''[[The Twelve Caesars]].'' ====Middle Eastern==== [[File:Wirth Gallery of the Middle East - Royal Ontario Museum - DSC09605.JPG|thumb|The ''Wirth Gallery of the Middle East'' explores civilizations from the [[Paleolithic|Palaeolithic Age]] to 1900 AD found within the [[Fertile Crescent]].]] The ''Wirth Gallery of the Middle East'' explores civilizations from the [[Paleolithic|Palaeolithic Age]] to 1900 AD found within the [[Fertile Crescent]], which stretches from the Eastern Mediterranean and [[History of Iran|Persia]] (Iran) and Iraq to the Arabian Peninsula. The over 1,000 artifacts relate to the writing, technology, spirituality, everyday life and warfare of the ancient [[Babylonia]]ns, [[Sumer]]ians, and [[Assyria]]ns. These civilizations made huge advances in writing, mathematics, law, medicine and religion, which are represented throughout the gallery.{{cite web|title=Wirth Gallery of the Middle East|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/galleries/world-cultures/wirth-gallery-middle-east|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=9 September 2013}} Pieces from the museum's collection that are featured at the ''Wirth Gallery of the Middle East'' include [[plastered human skulls]] made in the [[Levant]] c. 8000 BC.{{cite web|url=http://collections.rom.on.ca/objects/468283/plastered-human-skull?ctx=4953e3a8-c26c-4039-83d9-ee83f28a1770&idx=0|title=Plastered human skull|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|year=2018|accessdate=20 August 2018}} Another notable piece in the gallery is the [[Striding Lion]], a wall relief from the throne room of [[Nebuchadnezzar II]]'s palace.{{cite web|url=https://www.rom.on.ca/en/collections-research/rom-channel/iconic-striding-lion|title=Iconic: Striding Lion|date=9 October 2012|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=20 August 2018}} ==Offsite storage== Collections at the ROM not displayed are stored at various unclassified and offsite locations around the [[Greater Toronto Area]] and in the [[McLaughlin Planetarium]]. ==Accessibility== The ROM provides [[Accessibility|access]] for a wide range of communities.{{cite web|title=Accessibility|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/visit/access/|publisher=Royal Ontario Museum|accessdate=19 July 2012}} ===Accessibility services=== The ROM strives to recognize the diversity of visitor abilities and needs and offers programs and services to ensure accessibility for all and are available in both English and French.{{cite web|title=Access Programs and Services|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/visit-us/accessibility/access-programs-and-services|accessdate=22 May 2013}} These include: {{col div}} *Tactile tours that allow visitors to explore objects through touch *An audio description program that provides descriptive narration for people who are blind or have low vision *Tactile books featuring [[Braille]], raised line graphics, large print and colour pictures *Large-print guides *Hands-on galleries *Gallery interpreters that provide visitors with active exploration activities *[[American Sign Language]] (ASL) interpretation and tours *ASL video podcasts *Museum interactive touch screens *A hearing loop system *Assistive communication technology (Ubi-Duo), which allows real time communication between a deaf visitor and staff members {{col div end}} ===Royal Ontario Museum Community Access Network (ROMCAN)=== In 2008, ROMCAN was created to make the ROM more accessible to a variety of communities. ROMCAN provides free general admission tickets to participating community and charitable organizations. Each year, thousands of general admission tickets are distributed to these communities. ROMCAN tries to eliminate barriers that might stand between these communities and the museum. Since 2008, ROMCAN developed into a larger community initiative that seeks to enable learning experiences for visitors and organizations. A main goal of the program is to give the museum the power to engage, share and inspire a greater diversity of visitors by trying to break through economic and social barriers. Partners include United Way Toronto, [[Boys & Girls Clubs of Canada]], [[The Hospital for Sick Children]] and the [[Centre for Addiction and Mental Health]].{{cite web|title=Community Partner Profiles |url=http://www.rom.on.ca/visit/access/pdf/romcan_partners.pdf |publisher=Royal Ontario Museum |accessdate=19 July 2012 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==In popular culture== The novel ''[[Calculating God]]'' by Canadian [[science fiction]] author [[Robert J. Sawyer]] is mainly set in the ROM. The novel received nominations for both the [[Hugo Award|Hugo]] and [[John W. Campbell Memorial Award for Best Science Fiction Novel|John W. Campbell Memorial]] Awards in 2001.{{cite web | url = http://www.worldswithoutend.com/books_year_index.asp?year=2001 | title = 2001 Award Winners & Nominees | work = Worlds Without End | accessdate=27 March 2012 }} In the novel ''Bugs Potter Live at Nickaninny'' by Canadian children's author [[Gordon Korman]], one of the primary characters searching for the lost Naka-mee-chee (fictional) tribe was from the ROM. A large part of ''[[Life Before Man]],'' a [[novel]] by [[Canadians|Canadian]] writer [[Margaret Atwood]], takes place in ROM. Three of the four main characters of the novel work there. The museum is described in the novel in great detail, including the dinosaur gallery with its exhibits, contemporary to the time when the novel takes place. The novel was a finalist for the [[1979 Governor General's Awards|Governor General's Award]]. The museum was also filmed in several television shows. It was featured in ''[[Zoboomafoo]],'' an American-Canadian [[children's television series]] in the season 1 episode "Dinosaurs", where the Kratt brothers ([[Chris Kratt|Chris]] and [[Martin Kratt|Martin]] were invited to see the museum's dinosaur bones. The museum was also used as a filming location the [[police procedural]] [[Flashpoint (TV series)|''Flashpoint'']] for an episode of the third season. ==References== ''Galleries of the Royal Ontario Museum: Ancient Egypt and Nubia.'' 1994. Roberta L. Shaw and Krzysztof Grzymski. Royal Ontario Museum. {{ISBN|0-88854-411-1}}. {{reflist|3}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Royal Ontario Museum}} *{{Official website|http://www.rom.on.ca/en}} {{portalbar|Architecture|Toronto}} {{Royal Ontario Museum iconic objects}} {{Toronto landmarks}} {{Museums and galleries in Toronto}} {{ONGovDept}} {{Provincial museums of Canada}} [[Category:Royal Ontario Museum| ]] [[Category:Crown corporations of Ontario]] [[Category:Museums in Toronto]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Ontario]] [[Category:History museums in Ontario]] [[Category:Natural history museums in Canada]] [[Category:Asian art museums]] [[Category:Egyptological collections in Canada]] [[Category:Museums of ancient Greece]] [[Category:Museums of Ancient Near East]] [[Category:Museums of ancient Rome]] [[Category:Organizations based in Canada with royal patronage]] [[Category:Rotundas (architecture)]] [[Category:Museums established in 1914]] [[Category:1914 establishments in Ontario]] [[Category:Darling and Pearson buildings]] [[Category:Daniel Libeskind buildings]] [[Category:Art Deco architecture in Canada]]

{{Property law}} The '''Rule in Wild's Case''' is a [[common law]] rule of construction dating back to 1599 concerning a particular type of ambiguity in devises (such as grants or [[bequest]]s) of [[real property]]: If a grantor (O) grants, by [[deed]] or [[Will (law)|will]], property to another person (A) with the language ''"To A and her children"'', who gets lawful [[Possession (law)|possession]] of the property?
The rule resolves this ambiguity as follows: * If A has living children at the time of the grant, A and her children take the property as [[Concurrent estate|joint tenants]]. * If A does not have living children at the time of the grant, A takes the property in [[fee tail]].
This rule has fallen into disuse in those jurisdictions which no longer recognize the fee tail as a legal estate. Some [[U.S. state]]s ignore the rule altogether, and interpret such a grant as giving a [[life estate]] and creating a [[Remainder (law)|remainder]] in her children. Section 14.2 of the [[Restatement of the Law|Restatement (Third) of Property]] repudiates the Rule in Wild's Case, suggesting that many authorities consider it to be obsolete.
==References== [[Jesse Dukeminier|Dukeminier, Jesse]], Johansen, Stanley M., [[James Lindgren|Lindgren, James]], and [[Robert Sitkoff|Sitkoff, Robert]]. ''Wills, Trusts, and Estates, 7th Edition'', p. 664. Aspen Publishers, 2005. {{ISBN|0-7355-3695-3}}
==External links== * [http://www.answers.com/topic/rule-in-wild-s-case?cat=biz-fin Article from] [[Answers.com]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wilds Case}} [[Category:1599 in law]] [[Category:Real property law]] [[Category:Common law rules]] [[Category:Legal history of England]]

'''SIDSPACE''' is a [[mnemonic]] used in remembering which [[Latin]] [[preposition]]s take the [[ablative]] case.<ref name=a /><ref name=b />
SIDSPACE stands for the following prepositions: sub (during), in (at), de (about), sine (without), pro (before), ab (after), cum (with), and ex (from).<ref name=a>[http://www.gsgis.k12.va.us/facultyweb/cbroeniman/webpages/latin1_files/ablativeWorksheet.doc Ablative case review], Clifford Broeniman, Latin 1, Maggie L. Walker Governor's School for Government and International Studies. Accessed on line December 23, 2007.</ref><ref name=b>[http://schoolsite.capturepoint.com/assets/resources/Latin%20I%20Obj.pdf Ridgewood High School Latin I Curriculum- 12/05]. Accessed on line December 23, 2007.</ref> Although not all of these words take the [[ablative]] case in every context, all of them do take it some of the time. For example, 'in' takes the [[ablative]] case when expressing location, as in "He is in Italy," but takes the [[accusative case]] when it is expressing motion, such as "He went into Italy."
The mnemonic omits some of the less common prepositions, which are included in the rhyme:
:''A'', ''ab'', ''absque'', ''coram'', ''de'', :''palam'', ''clam'', ''cum'', ''ex'' or ''e'', :''sine'', ''tenus'', ''pro'' and ''prae''. :''Sub'', ''subter'', ''super'', ''in'' beside :when state not motion is implied.
A second version goes as follows:
:''A'', ''ab'', ''absque'', ''coram'', ''de'', :''palam'', ''clam'', ''cum'', ''ex'' or ''e'', :''sine'', ''tenus'', ''pro'' and ''prae'' :Govern the ablative every day. :To these, if ''rest at'' is intended, :''In'', ''sub'', ''super'', must be appended.
{''Sub'' means ''under'' and ''super'' means ''above''.)
A third version is as follows:
:A, ab, absque, coram, de, :Palam, clam, cum, ex and e, :Sine, tenus, pro and prae :Plus super, subter, sub and in :When rest not motion 'tis you mean.
==References== {{reflist}}
